Eli Manning Reflects on NFL Career, Rivalry with Tom Brady, and Excitement for NFC Divisional Round Matchup

Former New York Giants quarterback Eli Manning, a two-time Super Bowl champion, took a moment to reflect on his NFL career, the current playoffs, and the upcoming Drew Brees vs. Tom Brady showdown in the NFC Divisional round.

"It's been an incredible journey," Manning shared in an exclusive interview. "I'm really enjoying watching the playoffs and seeing some of the young talent out there. But there's one matchup in particular that I'm really looking forward to."

Manning's excitement was palpable as he spoke about the upcoming clash between his former rival, Tom Brady, and New Orleans Saints quarterback Drew Brees.

"Drew and Tom are two of the greatest quarterbacks to ever play the game," Manning said. "To see them go head-to-head at this stage in their careers is really something special."

Since retiring from the NFL, Manning has kept a low profile compared to his brother Peyton, engaging in charity work and brand endorsements. However, he still makes time for old teammates and friends, like Victor Cruz.

"Vic and I have been working on a Super Bowl food ideas initiative called Stella Stadium Bites," Manning explained. "It's been a great collaboration, and we're really excited about the potential impact we can make."

Reflecting on his storied rivalry with Brady, Manning emphasized the importance of team effort in their Super Bowl victories.

"We had some great battles against the Patriots, but it was never just about me and Tom," Manning said. "It was about our team and our ability to come together and execute when it mattered most."

Playing smart football against teams like the Patriots was a key factor in the Giants' success, Manning noted.

"You have to be disciplined and focused against them," he said. "They're a well-oiled machine, and you can't afford to make mistakes."

Manning's relationship with his brother Peyton has always been a source of inspiration and camaraderie.

"We've always had a great bond, both on and off the field," Manning said. "We love talking football and analyzing games together. It's just part of who we are."

Despite being considered the quieter Manning brother, Eli shared memories of watching Super Bowls with his family and the significance of such moments.

"Those are some of my favorite memories," he said. "Being able to share those experiences with my loved ones is something I'll always cherish."

Collaborating with Cruz on Super Bowl-related activities beyond his playing days has been a rewarding experience for Manning.

"Vic and I have a great chemistry, both on and off the field," he said. "It's been a pleasure to work with him on this project, and I know we're going to make a difference."

Manning expressed admiration for the longevity and skill of both Brees and Brady as they continue playing at a high level into their 40s.

"They're both still at the top of their game," Manning said. "It's a testament to their dedication and work ethic. I have a lot of respect for both of them."

As the NFC Divisional round matchup between the Saints and Buccaneers approaches, Manning is eager to see how the game unfolds and who will come out on top.

"It's going to be a great matchup," he said. "I'm just excited to watch and see how it all plays out."

Capitol Chaos: Lawmakers Condemn Rioters as 'Patriots,' Investigations Continue After Deadly Attempted Coup at US Capitol

The chaotic scene at the US Capitol on January 6th, 2021, as a mob of President Donald Trump's supporters stormed the building during the certification of the 2020 election results, has left the nation in shock. Amid the condemnation of the unprecedented violence, some lawmakers referred to the rioters as "patriots," fueling further division and controversy.

The riot was reportedly emboldened by President Trump and Republican rally attendees, including state lawmakers, who gathered in Washington D.C. to support Trump's efforts to overturn the election results. One GOP state lawmaker, Rep. Russell Fry of South Carolina, has already resigned following public backlash for attending the rally before the riot.

The rally, which drew thousands of supporters, was held to protest the certification of President-elect Joe Biden's electoral votes. Several Republican lawmakers, including Sens. Ted Cruz of Texas and Josh Hawley of Missouri, were present at the rally and addressed the crowd before the violent events unfolded.

The rioters, some of whom were armed, organized an attempted coup, storming the Capitol building as Congress was in the process of certifying the election results. At least five people, including one police officer, died during the event, and investigations into the riot's planning and execution are ongoing.

Members of the Proud Boys, a far-right extremist group classified as a hate group by the Southern Poverty Law Center, were reportedly present at the riot. The group's leader, Enrique Tarrio, was arrested earlier in the day for burning a Black Lives Matter banner taken from a historic Black church.

Amid the chaos, a Senate aide managed to secure the electoral vote boxes, ensuring they were not damaged during the riot. The Senate and House of Representatives eventually reconvened hours later and certified President-elect Biden's victory, with Vice President Mike Pence presiding over the joint session.

Trump, in a video message posted on Twitter shortly before the session resumed, called for an orderly transition and urged his supporters to go home peacefully. However, some Republicans have continued to question the election results, and calls for Trump's impeachment on charges of "incitement of an insurrection" have emerged.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has announced that she will begin the process of impeaching Trump for a second time, while some Democrats have also called for the expulsion of GOP lawmakers who supported the president's efforts to overturn the election results.

The riot at the Capitol has sparked widespread backlash against Republicans, with many Americans expressing outrage over the violence and the role that some GOP lawmakers played in fanning the flames of election conspiracy theories.

Social media platforms, including Twitter and Facebook, have taken steps to limit the spread of misinformation about the election and the events at the Capitol. Google and Apple have also removed the Parler app from their app stores, citing concerns over the platform's role in the spread of violent content.

The riot at the Capitol has raised serious concerns about the security of the US democratic process and the role of social media in shaping public discourse. Experts warn that the events of January 6th could have long-lasting implications for American democracy.

As the nation grapples with the aftermath of the Capitol riot, many are calling for unity and healing. However, the deep divisions that fueled the riot remain, and it remains to be seen how the country will move forward.

In the days and weeks ahead, the focus will shift to the incoming Biden administration and its plans to address the many challenges facing the nation. However, the events of January 6th serve as a reminder of the fragility of American democracy and the importance of respecting the rule of law.

New York's Nursing Home Scandal: Cuomo Brothers' Conflicted Coverage and the Alleged Underreporting of COVID-19 Deaths

New York Attorney General Letitia James shook the foundations of Governor Andrew Cuomo's administration when she claimed that the New York Department of Health (DOH) underreported COVID-19 nursing home deaths by as much as 50%. James' damning allegation, made in a report released on January 28, 2022, raised serious questions about the state's handling of the pandemic and its impact on vulnerable elderly residents.

William A. Jacobson, a media critic and Cornell Law School professor, did not mince words when reacting to the controversy. "Governor Cuomo directed nursing homes to accept COVID-positive patients, and now we learn that thousands more died than were reported," said Jacobson. "This is a massive scandal, and the fact that it involved the Cuomo brothers' relationship only adds to the intrigue."

As the scandal unfolded, it came to light that Governor Cuomo had directed nursing homes to accept COVID-19 patients, potentially contributing to the high death rates among elderly residents. CNN, where the governor's brother Chris Cuomo is a prominent anchor, faced intense criticism for its handling of the issue.

Steve Krakauer, a former CNN digital producer and media watchdog, weighed in on the controversy. "CNN's handling of the Cuomo brothers' interviews was a textbook example of a conflict of interest," Krakauer said. "The network should have been more transparent about the relationship and provided more nuanced coverage of the nursing home scandal."

When the nursing home controversy was finally addressed on CNN, Governor Cuomo deflected criticism jokingly. During a March 3, 2022, interview with his brother, Chris Cuomo asked, "What do you make of the allegation that New York underreported nursing home deaths?" To which the governor quipped, "I'd make a joke, but it's a little early in the morning."

Journalist Glenn Greenwald did not hold back in his criticism of CNN's handling of the scandal. "CNN's refusal to acknowledge the clear conflict of interest in their coverage of the Cuomo brothers only underscores the media's complicity in protecting powerful figures," Greenwald said.

Governor Cuomo, who had previously been lauded by the liberal media, authored a book on leadership, and received an Emmy Award, defended his nursing home policy. In a March 2, 2022, press conference, he blamed the Trump administration for COVID-related issues and argued that his policy was based on the best available science at the time.

Media watchdogs and commentators on both sides of the political spectrum criticized the coverage and handling of the Cuomo nursing home scandal. The controversy raised important questions about the role of the media in holding powerful figures accountable, and the potential consequences of conflicts of interest.

Letitia James, in her report, suggested that the mandated admission of COVID-19 patients into nursing homes may have increased residents' risk. The attorney general called for greater transparency and accountability in reporting nursing home deaths, stating, "We cannot allow this to happen again."

As the fallout from the nursing home scandal continues, the public remains divided on the issue. Some believe that the media should have been more transparent about the Cuomo brothers' relationship, while others argue that the focus should be on holding Governor Cuomo accountable for the state's handling of the pandemic. Regardless of where one stands on the issue, it is clear that the nursing home scandal has significantly impacted the reputations of both the Cuomo brothers and CNN.

William A. Jacobson weighed in on the broader implications of the scandal. "This is a wake-up call for the media and the public to demand greater transparency and accountability," Jacobson said. "The Cuomo nursing home scandal is a reminder that power and influence can't shield individuals from being held accountable for their actions."

As the investigation into the nursing home scandal continues, it remains to be seen what consequences Governor Cuomo and CNN will face. One thing is certain: the public will be watching closely to see how the media covers this developing story and whether they hold those in power accountable for their actions.

Glenn Greenwald, in a scathing critique, summed up the situation. "The media's handling of the Cuomo nursing home scandal is a clear example of why the public's trust in the media is at an all-time low," Greenwald said. "We need a media that is transparent, unbiased, and dedicated to the truth, not one that protects powerful figures at the expense of the public's wellbeing."

Steve Krakauer echoed Greenwald's sentiments. "The Cuomo nursing home scandal is a reminder that the media has a responsibility to the public to report the facts, not to protect the powerful," Krakauer said. "We need a media that is committed to holding those in power accountable, not one that turns a blind eye to conflicts of interest and scandals."

Letitia James, in her report, emphasized the importance of transparency and accountability in reporting nursing home deaths. "We cannot allow this to happen again," James said. "The public deserves to know the truth about the number of lives lost in New York's nursing homes during the pandemic."

President Biden's COVID-19 Strategy: 300 Million Doses Administered in 150 Days, Lowering Cases, Hospitalizations, and Deaths

WASHINGTON, D.C. – Today marks a significant milestone in our nation's fight against COVID-19: 300 million vaccine doses have been administered in just 150 days under President Biden's leadership. This achievement comes as we continue to see promising declines in COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths.

When President Biden took office on January 20, 2021, only 5% of adult Americans had been vaccinated, and the initial pace of vaccinations was slow. In response, the Biden Administration launched an ambitious COVID-19 strategy to ramp up vaccine production, distribution, and administration.

As of now, more than 175 million Americans have received at least one COVID-19 vaccine dose, representing over 54% of the total U.S. population. Among adult Americans, 65% have received at least one shot, and 55% are fully vaccinated.

The Biden Administration's efforts have been multi-faceted, focusing on securing a stable vaccine supply, increasing the number of vaccination sites, and mobilizing federal personnel to support vaccinations.

To date, over 81,000 vaccination sites have been established across the country, ensuring that Americans can easily get vaccinated within 5 miles of where they live. These sites include community health centers, hospitals, pharmacies, and mass vaccination sites.

The federal pharmacy vaccination program has expanded to 42,000 local pharmacies, which have administered over 82 million shots. This program has been crucial in expanding access to vaccines in underserved communities.

Additionally, the Biden Administration has set up 39 federally-run, high-volume vaccination sites, primarily in areas with high vulnerability to COVID-19. These sites have administered millions of doses and have played a critical role in increasing vaccination rates.

Community health centers have played a significant role in the vaccination effort, particularly for the poverty-line population and racial/ethnic minorities. These centers have hosted almost 11,000 pop-up clinics, ensuring that these communities have equitable access to vaccines.

The Biden Administration has prioritized equity in its COVID-19 response, with a majority of federally-provided shots going to people of color. The Administration has also provided support for over 20,000 community-based pop-up vaccination clinics.

President Biden's COVID-19 strategy has been successful in increasing vaccine distribution and administration, but it is essential that Americans continue to get vaccinated. The Administration encourages everyone who is eligible to get vaccinated as soon as possible to help protect themselves, their loved ones, and their communities.

COVID-19 vaccines are safe, effective, and free. They have undergone rigorous clinical trials and have been authorized for emergency use by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for all eligible individuals.

The Biden Administration remains committed to ensuring that every American has access to COVID-19 vaccines and the resources needed to get vaccinated. We will continue to work tirelessly to ensure that our country emerges from this pandemic stronger and more united than ever before.

Pelosi Announces Plan for Second Trump Impeachment as Democrats Push for Accountability

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) announced on Monday that Democrats are moving forward with impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump following the violent attack on the Capitol by his supporters. In a letter to her Democratic colleagues, Pelosi cited Trump as an "imminent threat" to democracy and the Constitution.

"In protecting our Constitution and our Democracy, we will act with urgency, because this President represents an imminent threat," Pelosi wrote in the letter.

Democrats are considering various measures, including an attempt to adopt Rep. Jamie Raskin's (D-MD) 25th Amendment resolution to remove Trump from office. They have also urged Vice President Mike Pence to take action against Trump.

Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) attempted to discuss the issue with Pence on Monday but did not connect. According to a Schumer spokesperson, "The Vice President did not provide any indication that he intends to invoke the 25th Amendment."

Meanwhile, drafted impeachment charges accuse Trump of inciting violence against the U.S. government. Pelosi aims for a vote as soon as Wednesday. However, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) has indicated that a trial is unlikely to start before President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20, which could affect early Biden administration actions.

Biden has not publicly taken a stand on impeachment, focusing instead on his upcoming agenda. Some Republicans, like Sen. Ben Sasse (R-NE), have shown openness to impeachment, while others, including McConnell, remain silent post-attack.

Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) stated, "I want him out. I want him out. He has caused enough damage." Sen. Pat Toomey (R-PA) added, "I believe the president of the United States incited this insurrection." However, Sen. Roy Blunt (R-MO) said, "I don't think the impeachment process is the best way to go."

Rep. James Clyburn (D-SC), a close ally of Biden, said, "I think impeachment is on the table. I think the 25th Amendment is on the table. But whatever we do, we have to do it in a way that does not interfere with the orderly transfer of power."

Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate in the House, called for Trump's immediate removal. "President Trump's continued presence in the White House is a clear and present danger to our nation," she said.

Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) and Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) have been criticized for their role in objecting to the certification of Electoral College votes. Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI) suggested possible expulsion for those objectors. Rep. Cori Bush (D-MO) went further, demanding Trump's arrest.

Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-WA) introduced articles of impeachment on Monday, which accuse Trump of "high crimes and misdemeanors" relating to the attack on the Capitol.

Sen. Chris Coons (D-DE) stated, "We can't allow what happened last week to stand as a precedent for the next administration or any administration. We have a Constitutional responsibility to act."

Archbishop of Canterbury Confirms Harry and Meghan's Wedding was Legal, Contradicting Oprah Interview

CNN – In an unexpected turn of events, the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, were indeed legally married before their public ceremony at St. George's Chapel in Windsor on May 19, 2018.

In a recent interview with Oprah Winfrey, Meghan revealed that they had a private exchange of vows three days before their wedding, which did not have any witnesses present. This led to speculation that the ceremony might not have been legally binding.

However, Welby clarified in a statement to CNN that he signed the legal document on the day of their public wedding, dispelling any doubts about the legitimacy of their marriage. "I signed the registration certificates, which are the legal documents, on the day of the wedding," Welby said.

Signing a false wedding certificate would have been a serious criminal offense, according to Welby, who emphasized the importance of truth and authenticity in marriage. "Marriage is a legal contract as well as a spiritual one," he explained. "It is essential that all the formalities are correctly followed to ensure that the couple's commitment to each other is legally recognized."

Despite this clarification, Harry and Meghan's interview with Oprah, which aired on March 7, 2021, contained several bombshell revelations, including allegations of racism within the royal family and Meghan's mental health struggles. One of the major revelations was concerns within the royal family about the skin color of their unborn child, Archie.

"In those moments, I knew that it was going to be really hard," Meghan told Oprah about her experience of pregnancy and motherhood. "And when I went to the institution, I thought that they would help, but instead, I was met with skepticism and scrutiny and some very negative feedback, others things that made me really question if this was the right place for me and my husband."

Prince Harry and Meghan Markle stepped back from their royal duties in January 2020, citing a desire for privacy and financial independence. Their interview with Oprah allowed them to speak more freely about their experiences in the royal family and the challenges they have faced since leaving.

In response to the allegations made in the interview, Buckingham Palace issued a statement saying, "The whole family is saddened to learn the full extent of how challenging the last few years have been for Harry and Meghan. The issues raised, particularly that of race, are concerning. While some recollections may vary, they are taken very seriously and will be addressed by the family privately."

Justin Welby's confirmation of the legality of Harry and Meghan's wedding comes as a relief to many, putting to rest any doubts about the validity of their marriage. However, the revelations in their Oprah interview are likely to continue to dominate headlines and fuel ongoing discussions about race, mental health, and the role of the royal family in modern society.

In conclusion, the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, has confirmed that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle were legally married before their public ceremony at St. George's Chapel in Windsor on May 19, 2018. The couple's interview with Oprah Winfrey, which aired on March 7, 2021, contained several major revelations, including allegations of racism within the royal family and Meghan's mental health struggles. Despite these challenges, Harry and Meghan remain committed to their relationship and their family, and their interview allowed them to speak more freely about their experiences in the royal family since leaving in January 2020.

Kamala Harris Makes History as First Female, Black Vice President; "We're Here, We're Part of This American Story"

WASHINGTON (AP) – Kamala Harris made history on Jan. 20 as the first female, Black, and South Asian American vice president of the United States. In her remarks at the Lincoln Memorial, Harris highlighted her inauguration as an exemplar of American aspiration and a significant step forward in gender and racial equality.

Harris was sworn in by Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, who herself made history as the first Latina justice in 2009. Harris used a Bible that once belonged to Thurgood Marshall, the first Black Supreme Court Justice, during the ceremony. Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman escorted Harris to the podium, harkening back to the heroism of law enforcement during the Capitol siege.

Lateefah Simon, a civil rights advocate and friend of Harris, said, "This moment is a testament to the resilience and determination of Black women in this country. Kamala Harris' election sends a powerful message that our voices and experiences matter."

Harris' inauguration is viewed as a watershed moment in American history, emphasizing the importance of Black women's leadership and representation. Elizabeth Shelby, a member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority, which Harris joined in college, shared her excitement, saying, "We're proud to have a sister leading the charge for progress and equality."

Martha S. Jones, a professor of history at Johns Hopkins University, commented, "Harris' election represents more than symbolic progress. It signals a realignment of political power in America, with Black women's voices and experiences at the table."

As Vice President, Harris presided over the Senate for the first time on Jan. 20, swearing in three new Democratic senators: Alex Padilla (California), Raphael Warnock (Georgia), and Jon Ossoff (Georgia). Harris had previously served as a senator from California and had run for the presidency herself.

President Joe Biden acknowledged the historical significance of Harris' election during his inaugural address, stating, "Today, we celebrate a milestone in our nation's history. Kamala Harris, the first woman, the first Black American, and the first South Asian American to be sworn in as Vice President of the United States."

The Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority and other organizations across the country celebrated Harris' inauguration. "We're thrilled to see one of our own making history," said Shelby. "It's a source of pride and inspiration for Black women everywhere."

Experts like Jones believe Harris' vice presidency will redefine political power in America, with her unique experiences and perspectives contributing to the administration's policies. Simon added, "Kamala Harris' election is a reminder that our diversity is our strength, and that every voice matters. We're here, we're part of this American story."

New Orleans' Trash Crisis: Residents Take to the Streets in Satirical Protest as Garbage Piles Up Weeks After Hurricane Ida

In the aftermath of Hurricane Ida's devastating impact on New Orleans, residents are grappling with an unexpected challenge: uncollected garbage piling up on their streets for weeks. The situation has reached a boiling point, prompting creative protests and sharp criticism of the local government.

During a City Council committee meeting on Sept. 21, residents testified about the uncollected trash that had accumulated before and after the hurricane hit on Aug. 29. "I've never seen anything like this in my life," said lifelong resident Carolyn Williams. "It's been over a month, and we still have trash on our streets."

Aaron 'Louisiana' Grant, a local artist and activist, proposed a solution with a satirical twist: a Trash Parade. He posted about the idea on Facebook, and it quickly gained over 1,900 interested participants. Grant's intention was to draw attention to the issue in a lighthearted yet impactful way.

Approximately 150 protesters participated in the Trash Parade on Sept. 25, showcasing their creativity with costumes made from discarded materials. "We wanted to make a statement, but also find joy in the chaos," Grant explained. "Humor is a powerful coping mechanism in the aftermath of a disaster."

Mayor LaToya Cantrell acknowledged the garbage collection problems during a press conference, attributing them to a workforce shortage exacerbated by Hurricane Ida. "We understand the frustration of our residents, and we're working to address this issue as quickly as possible," Cantrell said.

Despite the Trash Parade and the mayor's acknowledgment of the issue, trash remains visible throughout the city. Residents like Grant are growing increasingly frustrated with the lack of progress. "It's been over a month, and there's still no sign of improvement," Grant stated.

Grant's criticism of the local government's response extends beyond the trash crisis. "Where is the planning and preparation for situations like this?" he asked. "Why isn't sanitation a priority like electrical and healthcare services?"

The city is seeking help from outside contractors to address the sanitation crisis. However, residents like Grant remain skeptical. "We've seen promises before, and we'll believe it when we see it," he said.

Mayor Cantrell emphasized the importance of patience and understanding during this difficult time. "We're doing everything we can to get our city back on its feet," she said. "But it's going to take time, and we need everyone's cooperation and understanding."

Grant and other residents aren't willing to wait indefinitely. "We can't let this become the new normal," he said. "We deserve better, and we're going to keep pushing for it."

As the Trash Parade came to a close, participants took to social media to express their frustration and solidarity. "#TrashParadeNOLA: When the city can't handle the trash, we will," one participant wrote. "Together, we'll clean up New Orleans, one parade at a time."

The Trash Parade may have been a satirical protest, but it highlighted a serious issue that affects the lives and well-being of New Orleans residents. With the help of outside contractors and the resilience of the community, the city is working to overcome this challenge and restore normalcy. But for many, the memory of the Trash Parade serves as a reminder of the importance of holding their elected officials accountable for the services they provide.

House Impeaches Trump for Second Time, Charging Him with 'Incitement of Insurrection'

WASHINGTON (AP) – In a historic and bipartisan vote, the U.S. House of Representatives impeached President Donald Trump for a second time Wednesday, charging him with "incitement of insurrection" following the violent Capitol riot. The proceeding came as lawmakers convened to certify President-elect Joe Biden's election victory.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) opened the debate by urging her colleagues to uphold their constitutional duties. "We are here today because the president of the United States incited this insurrection, this armed rebellion against our common country," Pelosi said.

The House voted 232-197 to impeach Trump, with ten Republicans joining Democrats, marking the most bipartisan presidential impeachment in modern times. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) and other top House Republicans opposed the effort.

McCarthy asserted that impeachment was a "rash rush to judgment." Republican Reps. Liz Cheney of Wyoming, the third-ranking House GOP leader, and Adam Kinzinger of Illinois were two of the 10 Republicans who voted in favor of impeachment.

House Democrats argued that Trump's incendiary rhetoric and falsehoods about the election outcome incited a mob that stormed the Capitol, interrupting the certification of election results. Rep. Jim McGovern (D-Mass.) expressed concern for the safety of lawmakers and the democratic process.

"This is not a game. This is a matter of life and death, and it's time for us to take action," McGovern said. Rep. Jason Crow (D-Colo.) described the events as "an attack on our democracy."

Republican Reps. Maxine Waters (Calif.), Tom McClintock (Calif.), Pat Toomey (Pa.), and Lisa Murkowski (Alaska) were among the Republicans who broke ranks to support impeachment.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) indicated Trump had committed impeachable offenses but has not decided how he will vote in the Senate trial. McConnell issued a statement saying, "The mob was fed wild falsehoods that, in turn, provoked violence."

The earliest the Senate could start an impeachment trial is the day before Trump's term ends, aiming also to prevent him from running again. The impeachment resolution relies on Trump's incendiary rhetoric and falsehoods about the election outcome, which Trump continued to promote even after the riot.

In response, Trump released a video statement calling for unity and condemning the violence but did not mention the impeachment. "Mob violence goes against everything I believe in and everything our movement stands for," Trump said.

Security was tightened at the Capitol, including metal-detector screenings for House members, reflecting heightened concerns. This impeachment proceeding drew on historical precedents, including the impeachment of War Secretary William Belknap in 1876 after his resignation.

Tom Brady's Quest for Super Bowl Glory: Chasing Records with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers

Tom Brady, widely regarded as the most successful quarterback in NFL history, is gearing up for another shot at Super Bowl glory with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Brady, a six-time Super Bowl champion, will aim to add another Vince Lombardi Trophy to his impressive collection when the Buccaneers face the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl 55.

Brady's accomplishments in the Super Bowl are unmatched. He holds numerous records, including the most wins (6), games played (9), and MVP awards (4). Brady's dominance on the sport's biggest stage is a testament to his exceptional talent and determination.

Despite Brady's influence, the Buccaneers' postseason win record remains modest. Brady joined the team mid-season, leading them to a 7-5 record before the playoffs. The Buccaneers went on to defeat the Washington Football Team, New Orleans Saints, and Green Bay Packers to reach the Super Bowl.

Brady's Super Bowl records extend beyond wins and MVP awards. He holds the records for most pass attempts (1,029), pass completions (671), pass completions in a single game (41), passing yards (8,610), and touchdown passes (36). Brady's ability to perform under pressure and lead his team to victory is unparalleled.

Brady has the opportunity to break even more records at Super Bowl 55. He is currently tied with Terry Bradshaw and Joe Montana for the most NFL championships with six. A win in Super Bowl 55 would allow Brady to take sole possession of this record. Brady's personal best of four touchdown passes in a single Super Bowl is third highest, with Steve Young holding the record at six. Brady also has the chance to break the record for most touchdown passes in a single Super Bowl, currently held by Tom Jackson at five.

Brady has thrown six interceptions in his Super Bowl appearances, placing him fourth all time in interceptions during Super Bowl play. Brady's interceptions-per-game average in the Super Bowl is 0.2, significantly lower than John Elway's 0.4. Despite playing in nearly double the number of Super Bowls as Elway, Brady trails Elway in total interceptions thrown, with 14 to Brady's 15.

Brady's pursuit of Super Bowl records began when he led the New England Patriots to their first title in Super Bowl 36. Since then, Brady has continued to break records and redefine what it means to be an elite quarterback. Brady's ability to perform under pressure and lead his team to victory has made him a legend in the NFL.

Brady's journey to Super Bowl 55 with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers has been a unique one. He joined the team mid-season, leading them to the playoffs and ultimately to the Super Bowl. Brady's impact on the Buccaneers has been significant, and he will aim to add another Super Bowl title to his already impressive resume.

Brady's quest for more Super Bowl records is a testament to his exceptional talent and determination. He continues to push the boundaries of what is possible for a quarterback, and his pursuit of greatness shows no signs of slowing down. As Brady prepares for Super Bowl 55, fans and analysts alike will be watching closely to see if he can add to his already impressive list of Super Bowl records.

In conclusion, Tom Brady's pursuit of Super Bowl glory and records with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers is a testament to his exceptional talent and determination. With six Super Bowl titles, numerous records, and the opportunity to break even more records, Brady continues to redefine what it means to be an elite quarterback in the NFL. As he prepares for Super Bowl 55, fans and analysts alike will be watching closely to see if he can add to his already impressive list of accomplishments.

Former CNN Producer John Griffin Indicted for Allegedly Luring Minors for Sexual Acts, Faces Decades in Prison

New York Post

Former CNN producer John Griffin, 64, was indicted this week on federal charges of attempting to sexually exploit minors and faces up to 10 years in prison for each of the three counts involving a 9-year-old girl, according to a press release from the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

The disturbing allegations against Griffin came to light after an explicit text message exchange between him and a victim was discovered by the victim's biological mother. The messages revealed that Griffin offered large sums of money to women and their daughters for sexual acts, including in the presence of minors.

US Attorney Nikolas P. Kerest emphasized the need to keep Griffin detained for community safety. "The defendant in this case, John Griffin, is a wealthy man who attempted to use his wealth to influence the legal process," Kerest said in a statement. "Despite his previous privilege, he now faces substantial legal and reputational risks."

U.S. Concludes Afghanistan War: From 9/11 Attacks to Troop Withdrawal, a 20-Year Journey

Aug 30 (Reuters) – Twenty years after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States that were orchestrated from Afghanistan, the last U.S. troops departed the war-torn country on Aug. 30, marking the end of America's longest conflict.

U.S. General Frank McKenzie, Head of U.S. Central Command, confirmed the completion of the withdrawal, stating, "The mission to evacuate Americans, third-country nationals, and vulnerable Afghans from Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul is now complete."

Sept. 11, 2001, was a day that changed the world when al Qaeda terrorists hijacked four commercial airplanes and crashed two into the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York City and one into the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia. The fourth plane, United Airlines Flight 93, crashed into a field in Pennsylvania after passengers tried to regain control from the hijackers.

Oct. 7, 2001, saw U.S. forces launch airstrikes against Taliban and al Qaeda targets in Afghanistan with no significant initial combat deployment.

In late 2001, Osama bin Laden, the mastermind behind the 9/11 attacks, narrowly escaped U.S. bombing in Tora Bora, Afghanistan, and fled to Pakistan.

On May 2, 2003, then-President George W. Bush declared an end to major combat operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, shifting the focus to stabilization efforts. This move enabled the Taliban to regain strength.

On Feb. 17, 2009, President Barack Obama increased U.S. troops in Afghanistan, exceeding 100,000 in 2010 for counter-insurgency operations.

Fast forward to May 1, 2011, when U.S. forces killed bin Laden in Abbottabad, Pakistan, during a covert operation.

In May 2014, Obama initiated a drawdown, focusing on training Afghan military and planning a full withdrawal by the end of 2016.

On Feb. 29, 2020, the Trump administration signed an agreement with the Taliban for U.S. troop withdrawal and Taliban negotiations for peace.

The end of U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan came amidst chaos and tragedy. An ISIS suicide bomb at Kabul airport on Aug. 26, 2021, killed scores, including 13 U.S. troops and 170 Afghans.

McKenzie acknowledged the challenges ahead, stating, "This is not the end, but rather the beginning of a new chapter in Afghanistan's history. The international community must continue to support the Afghan people as they build a peaceful, prosperous, and self-reliant future."

The current focus of our counterterrorism strategy will be on an over-the-horizon capability. Our commitment to the security of the American people remains our top priority.

Let me be clear: the decision to withdraw was not an easy one. There was never a 'good time' to withdraw U.S. forces from Afghanistan. But we cannot continue to bear the burden of fighting a conflict that Afghan forces are not willing to fight for themselves. We have provided significant support to the Afghan military over the years, but we could not instill the will to fight for their future.

I want to acknowledge the pain and personal impact of this war, especially for our veterans and their families. Your sacrifices will never be forgotten. We will continue to support you and provide the resources you need to heal and reintegrate into society.

Now, let me speak directly to the people of Afghanistan. I want you to know that the United States does not seek perpetual conflict in your country. We want you to live in peace and security. But we cannot support a government that cannot unite politically and negotiate a political settlement with the Taliban.

The rapid collapse of Afghan political leadership and military is a reinforcement of the decision to withdraw. The Taliban's takeover was not inevitable. The Afghan people had the power to determine their own future, but they chose not to seize the opportunity.

We will continue to work with our allies to prevent Afghanistan from becoming a safe haven for terrorist organizations once again. Trump and his allies lost accounts on multiple platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Twitch, Spotify, and Shopify, following the Capitol riot. The bans deprived them of the ability to reach new audiences and curbed their momentum to spread false claims.

Leysia Palen, an information science professor at the University of Colorado, noted that while de-platforming can be effective in limiting the reach of disinformation, it may also harden the views of those already engaged in online communities.

The Twitter ban was part of a broader social media crackdown, with Twitter banning over 70,000 QAnon-affiliated accounts in the days following the riot. The use of hashtags affiliated with the Capitol riot dropped considerably after the ban.

Media Matters for America, a liberal media watchdog group, reported a significant fall in interactions on right-leaning political Facebook pages following the Capitol riot. The group found that interactions on pages like Breitbart, Gateway Pundit, and The Epoch Times dropped by an average of 30% after the riot.

Few accounts acted as "superspreaders" of election misinformation, with Trump's account being a major source. Starbird noted that a small number of accounts were responsible for the majority of the disinformation. These accounts, she said, "were able to amplify a large amount of content very quickly."

Advance Democracy, a nonprofit organization that monitors disinformation, found a decrease in election fraud claims following the Capitol riot. However, violent narratives continued to spread at the peripheries of online communities.

Starbird cautioned against complacency, noting that "new actors and new narratives are constantly emerging." She urged social media companies to continue their efforts to combat disinformation and maintain transparency in their content moderation policies.

Brookie emphasized the importance of continued research and collaboration between social media companies, researchers, and policymakers in the fight against disinformation. He called for a "multi-stakeholder approach" to addressing the issue.

Palen emphasized the need for individuals to fact-check information before sharing it online and to engage in constructive dialogue with those holding opposing views. "We all have a role to play in creating a more informed public," she said.

In conclusion, the Twitter ban on Donald Trump marked a significant turning point in the fight against election disinformation. While the decline in disinformation is a positive development, it is crucial that social media companies, researchers, policymakers, and individuals remain vigilant in the face of new actors and narratives.

Federal Indictment: Derek Chauvin and Three Former Officers Face Civil Rights Charges in George Floyd's Death

In a significant turn of events in the high-profile case of George Floyd's death, Derek Chauvin and three other former Minneapolis police officers, J. Alexander Kueng, Thomas Lane, and Tou Thao, were federally indicted on Friday, February 11, for violating Floyd's civil rights under color of law.

According to the indictment unsealed in the U.S. District Court in Minnesota, the officers are charged with depriving Floyd of his rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, including the use of unreasonable force and deliberate indifference to his medical needs.

"This indictment reflects the Justice Department's commitment to ensuring that all Americans receive equal protection under the law, regardless of their race or their status as a law enforcement officer," said U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland in a statement.

Mark Osler, a former federal prosecutor and professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law, commented on the significance of the federal charges, stating, "Federal civil rights cases are a big deal because they carry a potential for much longer prison sentences than the state charges."

Chauvin, who was convicted on state charges of murder and manslaughter in Floyd's death last year, also faces separate federal charges related to a 2017 incident involving the use of excessive force against a 14-year-old.

Kenneth Udoibok, a civil rights lawyer and managing partner at Udoibok Law Firm in Minneapolis, shared his thoughts on the importance of the federal charges, "This is a significant development in the pursuit of justice for George Floyd and his family. The federal indictment reaffirms that no one is above the law and that law enforcement personnel must be held accountable for their actions."

Rachel Moran, an associate professor of law at the University of St. Thomas, explained the standard the prosecution must meet to convict the officers, "The government must prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the officers' actions were willful violations of Floyd's civil rights under color of law."

Rebeccah Parks, spokesperson for the U.S. District Court in Minnesota, confirmed that the proceedings' dates have not been set and that they are unlikely to be broadcast, unlike the high-profile state trials.

Federal civil rights charges against law enforcement officers are relatively rare, with an average of 41 cases brought annually between 1990 and 2019, according to a study by the National Police Foundation.

Experts and legal professionals agree that a federal conviction could result in severe penalties, potentially carrying sentences of 20 years to life in prison for each offense.

In light of the new federal charges, plea negotiations could potentially affect the outcomes for the officers in both the state and federal cases, according to Osler. However, he emphasized that such discussions are still speculative at this stage of the proceedings.

The federal charges against Chauvin and the other officers add another layer of complexity to the already intricate legal landscape surrounding George Floyd's death. The events that transpired on May 25, 2020, continue to spark national conversations about police accountability, racial justice, and the role of the criminal justice system.

As the legal proceedings unfold, the public awaits the outcome of these cases with a renewed sense of anticipation and hope for a measure of justice for George Floyd and his family.

German Court Rules Facebook Acted Illegally in Removing Racist Posts, Adding Complexity to Election Debate

BERLIN, July 29 – In a landmark decision, a top German court ruled that Facebook acted illegally by taking down racist posts and blocking the author's account without notification or explanation, adding complexity to the debate on toxic discourse on social networks ahead of the country's general election.

The Federal Court of Justice's verdict, which overturned a lower court's decision, is significant as the comments in question violated Facebook's community standards on hate speech, which is also banned under German law. However, the court declared Facebook's terms of service regarding post deletion and account blocking for community standards violations as "null and void."

"We are reviewing the judgment to continue effectively removing hate speech in Germany while ensuring the rights of our users," a Facebook company spokesperson told Reuters in a statement. The spokesperson emphasized Facebook's zero-tolerance policy for hate speech.

The specific post cited in the court ruling criticized German handling of "Islamist immigrants," alleging impunity for murder and rape. The post called for action from the Office for the Protection of the Constitution, Germany's main domestic security agency.

Google also sought judicial review of a new German law (NetzDG) this week, citing privacy concerns due to the law's provisions for data sharing with law enforcement.

The court's criticism of Facebook for not committing to inform users about post removal, account blocking reasons, or offering a right of appeal, raises questions about how social media platforms can balance free speech with the need to prevent hate speech and incitement to violence.

"The right to freedom of expression is a fundamental right, but it is not absolute. It is subject to the general prohibition of hate speech and incitement to violence," the court said in its ruling.

Facebook's zero-tolerance policy on hate speech has been under scrutiny in recent years, with critics arguing that the platform does not do enough to prevent the spread of hate speech and misinformation. The company has faced criticism for its handling of posts that violate its community standards, particularly in the run-up to elections.

The court's ruling is expected to have far-reaching implications for social media companies operating in Germany, as they will now be required to provide users with more transparency regarding post removal and account blocking.

"This is a significant step towards ensuring that social media platforms are held accountable for their actions in removing hate speech and protecting the rights of their users," said Jens Markwart, a legal expert at the German Digital Association.

The debate on toxic discourse on social networks has gained urgency ahead of Germany's general election, scheduled for September 26, 2021. Political parties and advocacy groups have called on social media platforms to do more to prevent the spread of hate speech and misinformation.

The court's ruling comes as social media companies face increasing pressure to address the issue of toxic discourse on their platforms, particularly in the context of elections. Facebook and other social media companies have faced criticism for their handling of posts that violate community standards, particularly in the run-up to elections.

The court's ruling is likely to be closely watched by other European countries, which have also been grappling with the issue of hate speech and incitement to violence on social media platforms. The European Union has proposed new regulations that would force social media companies to take down hate speech within 24 hours of being notified or face fines.

In conclusion, the German Federal Court of Justice's ruling that Facebook acted illegally by taking down racist posts and blocking the author's account without notification or explanation adds complexity to the debate on toxic discourse on social networks ahead of Germany's general election. The court's criticism of Facebook for not committing to inform users about post removal, account blocking reasons, or offering a right of appeal raises questions about how social media platforms can balance free speech with the need to prevent hate speech and incitement to violence. The ruling is expected to have far-reaching implications for social media companies operating in Germany and beyond.

Stimulus Checks and Child Tax Credit Payments Ending in 2021: What's Next for Families?

BALTIMORE (WBFF/WKRC) – The American Rescue Plan, which included $1,400 stimulus check payments for most Americans and expanded Child Tax Credit benefits, is coming to an end in 2021. Here's what you need to know about the payments and what's next for families.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has sent out the third round of Economic Impact Payments to eligible individuals based on their 2019 or 2020 tax filings. The payments, which totaled up to $1,400 for individuals and $2,800 for married couples, were designed to help Americans cope with the financial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

However, no more monthly Child Tax Credit payments are planned for 2022. The expanded Child Tax Credit benefits, which provided up to $3,600 per child under the age of 6 and up to $3,000 per child between the ages of 6 and 17, have been a lifeline for many families.

Some families, however, may be eligible for "plus-up" payments based on changes noted in their 2020 tax filings. These changes include lower income or having a child. The IRS will send out "plus-up" payments until December 31, based on the legislative deadline.

It's important to note that Economic Impact Payments are available for individuals making $75,000 or less, or married couples making $150,000 or less. If you believe you are eligible but haven't received a payment, you can use the IRS's Get My Payment tool to check your payment status.

Democrats, meanwhile, are planning to continue efforts to extend the Child Tax Credit payments into 2022. A one-year extension of the Child Tax Credit would cost an estimated $185 billion, while extending the credit for 10 years would cost approximately $1.6 trillion, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.

President Biden has expressed support for extending the Child Tax Credit, but it remains to be seen whether Democrats will be able to pass the legislation in a divided Congress. In the meantime, families are encouraged to take advantage of the expanded benefits while they last.

As the year comes to a close, it's important for families to understand the timeline for these payments and what to expect moving forward. The IRS has provided resources and tools to help individuals check their payment status and ensure they are receiving the benefits they are eligible for.

In conclusion, the American Rescue Plan's stimulus check payments and expanded Child Tax Credit benefits are coming to an end in 2021. While some families may be eligible for "plus-up" payments based on changes to their income or family size, it remains to be seen whether Democrats will be able to extend the Child Tax Credit into 2022. Gabby Petito: Teton County Coroner Identifies Remains as Missing 22-Year-Old; Homicide Investigation Underway

Body discovered in Wyoming identified as Gabby Petito, 22-year-old reported missing earlier this month, Teton County Coroner Brent Blue confirmed to CBS News on Tuesday. The initial manner of death has been ruled a homicide, but the cause of death is pending final autopsy results.

"The body found today in Grand Teton National Park has been identified as Gabrielle Venora Petito. The cause and manner of death are still under investigation," Blue stated.

FBI Denver, along with other law enforcement agencies, completed a forensic search of the Spread Creek Dispersed Camping Area where the body was discovered, asking anyone in the area from August 27-30 to contact investigators. The FBI emphasized its commitment to holding those responsible for Petito's death accountable.

"The FBI and our partners remain dedicated to bringing justice to Gabby Petito and her family," said FBI Denver Special Agent in Charge Michael Schneider. "We ask anyone with information or who may have seen something suspicious in or around Grand Teton National Park, the Moab, Utah, area, or the Blue Point, Long Island, New York, area, between August 27 and September 11, 2021, to contact the FBI tip line at 1-800-CALL-FBI (225-5324) or tips.fbi.gov."

Richard Benson Stafford, attorney for Petito's family, thanked the press for giving the family time to grieve.

"Gabby's family would like to express their sincere gratitude to the FBI, the National Park Service, the Suffolk County Police Department, and the North Port Police Department for their tireless efforts in searching for Gabby," Stafford stated. "The family asks that their privacy be respected during this difficult time as they process the tragic loss of their beloved Gabby."

As investigators search for Petito's fiancé, Brian Laundrie, in Florida's Carlton Reserve, his whereabouts remain unknown. Laundrie was reportedly last seen on September 13, driving the couple's Ford Transit van.

On August 12, Moab City Police responded to a domestic dispute between the couple, which was classified as a 'mental health break.' According to the report, no significant injuries were observed, and no arrests were made.

Petito's last known contact with her family was in late August, and she was reported missing on September 11. Petito's friend, Rose Davis, expressed profound disappointment and called Laundrie a 'coward' in an interview with CBS News.

"I was really looking forward to her getting married and starting her life," Davis stated. "It's just really tragic and heartbreaking that it ended this way. Brian Laundrie is a coward, and he needs to turn himself in."

The investigation into Petito's disappearance and death is ongoing, with the FBI, North Port Police Department, Suffolk County Police Department, and Teton County Sheriff's Office collaborating on the case. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact the FBI.

East Coast Transit Systems Struggle with Climate Resilience as Storms Intensify

NEW YORK (AP) – Hurricane Ida's devastating winds and torrential rains exposed the vulnerabilities of East Coast transit systems to extreme weather events, highlighting the urgent need for improved climate resilience. Since Superstorm Sandy in 2012, billions have been spent on coastal flooding protection, but recent events underscore that more work is necessary.

Janno Lieber, acting CEO of New York City's Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA), acknowledged the challenges. "We've made progress since Sandy, but it's clear we need to do more," Lieber said.

Proposed solutions include constructing canals in New York City and installing curbs at subway entrances to prevent water ingress. Sanjay Seth, Boston's climate resilience program manager, highlighted the city's focus on the Blue Line, with plans for a seawall and upgraded pumps.

In Boston, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (MBTA) spent over $100 million on post-Sandy flood protection measures, but Joe Pesaturo, an MBTA spokesperson, admitted mixed success during this summer's storms. "We've seen some improvements, but there's still work to be done," Pesaturo said.

In Philadelphia, the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority (SEPTA) has continued armoring shorelines with concrete blocks. Bob Lund, SEPTA's deputy general manager, believes this approach is still effective. "Concrete is a proven solution against storm surges," Lund stated.

Washington D.C.'s WMATA is developing a climate resiliency plan and has already upgraded its drainage systems and installed pumping stations. Sherrie Ly, WMATA spokesperson, emphasized the importance of preparedness. "We're taking a proactive approach to ensure our infrastructure can withstand future storms," Ly said.

However, there are concerns whether transit systems are planning ambitiously enough for climate change challenges. Jesse Keenan, an associate professor at Tulane University, emphasized the need for long-term strategies. "Transit systems need to think beyond just repairing damage after each storm," Keenan stated.

Michael Martello, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, agrees. "We need to invest in infrastructure that can adapt to a changing climate," Martello said.

Yet, funding remains a major challenge for implementing ambitious climate change projects in transit systems. Seth from Boston acknowledged the issue. "Money is always a concern, but we're committed to finding solutions," he said.

Global cities like London and Zhengzhou, China, also struggle with flood management in their transit systems. London's Transport for London has invested billions in upgrades, while Zhengzhou's metro system was flooded during record-breaking rainfall in July 2021.

As the frequency and intensity of storms increase, East Coast transit systems must continue to adapt and invest in climate resilience. The future of urban transportation depends on it.
