Millions of Families Set to Receive Child Tax Credit Payments Worth $15 Billion in August

BALTIMORE (WBFF/WKRC) – The expanded Child Tax Credit, a key provision of the American Rescue Plan Act initiated in March, is set to distribute about $15 billion in payments to approximately 61 million children across the United States this August. This represents a significant financial boost for families with young children.

The first installment of the monthly payments is scheduled for direct deposit on August 15, with mailed checks arriving a few days later. Eligible families with children under 18 years old will receive $300 per child under the age of 6 and $250 per child between 6 and 17.

August's payment marks the third in a series of six monthly payments planned for 2021. The first half of the credit is being distributed through these monthly checks, with the remaining amount to be received during tax filing in 2022.

To be eligible for the full Child Tax Credit, families must have at least one child under the age of 18. However, eligibility begins to phase out for incomes exceeding $150,000 for joint filers, $112,500 for heads of households, and $75,000 for single filers. The phaseout reduces the Child Tax Credit by $50 for each $1,000 above the income threshold.

In July, an error in the direct deposit process affected approximately 15% of recipients, causing delays or incorrect payments. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is working to resolve the issue and expects a smoother process for this month's payment.

Families who received checks will receive a letter from the IRS at the end of the year. This letter is necessary for tax filing in 2022 and should be kept for record-keeping purposes. The letter will include the total amount of Child Tax Credit payments received during the year.

The American Rescue Plan Act, signed into law by President Joe Biden on March 11, 2021, aims to provide economic relief to families and individuals affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The expanded Child Tax Credit is a significant component of this relief package.

The Child Tax Credit has a long history in the United States, first enacted in 1997 and expanded several times since then. The current expansion represents the most substantial increase in the credit's value since its inception.

The Child Tax Credit is not the only provision of the American Rescue Plan Act designed to support families. The act also includes a temporary expansion of the Earned Income Tax Credit and the Child and Dependent Care Credit, as well as an increase in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits.

Advocacy groups and policymakers have called for the expansion of the Child Tax Credit to be made permanent. They argue that the credit provides crucial financial support for families and helps reduce child poverty. However, the future of the expanded Child Tax Credit remains uncertain, as it is currently set to expire at the end of 2021.

As families prepare for this month's Child Tax Credit payment, they are encouraged to check their eligibility and update their bank information with the IRS to ensure timely and accurate payments. For more information on the Child Tax Credit and other provisions of the American Rescue Plan Act, visit the IRS website or consult a tax professional.

15-Year-Old Michigan Student Charged with Murder, Terrorism after School Shooting that Killed Four

OXFORD TOWNSHIP, Mich. (AP) – A 15-year-old student, Ethan Crumbley, was charged with four counts of murder and one count of terrorism following a shooting at Oxford High School in Michigan that left four students dead and seven others injured, authorities announced on Monday.

Prosecutor Karen McDonald and Sheriff's Lt. Tim Willis revealed during a press conference that Crumbley had recorded a video discussing plans to kill students at the school. The shooting, they said, was premeditated.

"Based on our investigation, we believe this was not an impulsive act," McDonald said.

Scott Kozak, defense attorney for the Crumbley family, entered a not guilty plea on Ethan's behalf during a brief court appearance on Monday.

According to authorities, Crumbley faced 24 charges, including murder and attempted murder. He was charged as an adult.

The shooting occurred hours after a concerning meeting between Crumbley's parents and school officials about his behavior, officials said.

McDonald stated, "The parents were contacted and met with school officials regarding Ethan's behavior and his mental health, hours before the shooting."

Crumbley's father, James Crumbley, had purchased the 9 mm Sig Sauer gun used in the shooting just a week prior, authorities added.

This was the deadliest school shooting in the U.S. since Santa Fe High School in 2018, marking it among 31 mass killings in the year.

McDonald highlighted the need for stricter gun laws and considered charges against Crumbley's parents for failing to secure the firearm.

"Families need to keep their guns secured and out of the reach of children," McDonald said. "This isn't a political issue, it's a community safety issue."

The terrorism charge was emphasized due to the broader impact on students, families, and the community.

"The terrorism charge was added because of the impact on the community and the severity of the incident," Assistant Prosecutor Marc Keast explained.

Mike Bouchard, Oakland County Sheriff, urged the public to report any threats to officials and cautioned against spreading rumors on social media.

"We need the public's help," Bouchard said. "If you see something, say something. Do not spread rumors on social media."

The community of Oxford Township was left reeling from the tragedy. Counselors were made available for students and families.

McDonald expressed her condolences, saying, "Our hearts go out to the families and friends of the victims. This is a tragic day for our community."

Authorities continued their investigation into the shooting, urging anyone with information to come forward.

"We will continue to work closely with school officials and law enforcement to ensure the safety and well-being of our students and staff," Oxford Community Schools Superintendent Tim Throne said in a statement. "Our focus remains on supporting our students, families, and staff during this difficult time."

Stimulus Checks Amidst the Pandemic: Household Expenses, Debt Payments, and Savings

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, Americans have received over $850 billion in Economic Impact Payments, or stimulus checks, from the CARES Act in March 2020, the Consolidated Appropriations Act in December 2020, and the American Rescue Plan Act in March 2021. These funds have provided much-needed relief to millions of households as they navigated the financial challenges posed by the crisis.

According to a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, 75% of recipients used their first stimulus check for household expenses amidst the April 2020 unemployment spike. This spending was primarily focused on necessities such as food, rent, and utilities.

However, spending patterns shifted in the second and third checks. A survey by the JPMorgan Chase Institute revealed that 22% of recipients spent their second stimulus check, while 26% saved it and 51% used it to pay down debt. With the third stimulus check, 19% were spent, 32% were saved, and 49% were used to pay off debt.

Stimulus checks were targeted towards low and middle-income households, with a decline in benefits for those earning over $75,000. According to the Urban Institute, the average household in the bottom 20% of the income distribution received $2,464 from the three stimulus packages, while those in the top 20% received an average of $1,332.

High-income households were more likely to save or pay off debt with their stimulus checks. In contrast, lower-income households were more likely to spend the funds on necessities. This trend was also observed in the Consumer Expenditure Survey by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

These stimulus checks may have contributed to increases in personal income, consumer spending, savings, and economic growth. According to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, personal income grew at an annual rate of 11.4% in the first quarter of 2021, thanks in part to the third stimulus check.

However, a fourth stimulus check is unlikely at this time. President Biden has instead focused on a $2.3 trillion infrastructure package, which includes provisions for job creation, education, and climate change.

More than 80 members of Congress support $2,000 monthly checks until the end of the pandemic, but lack significant support from their Republican colleagues. Proponents argue that these checks would provide much-needed relief to struggling households and boost the economy.

Critics, however, argue that the checks would disproportionately benefit high-income households and would add to the federal deficit. They also point to the success of the vaccination rollout and the improving employment situation as reasons to phase out the checks.

Despite the debate over a fourth stimulus check, it is clear that the previous three checks have had a significant impact on American households. For many, they provided a crucial lifeline during a time of financial uncertainty.

The survey by the JPMorgan Chase Institute also revealed that recipients of the third stimulus check were more likely to save or pay off debt than those who received the first check. This trend could be attributed to the improving economic conditions and the availability of vaccines.

However, not all households have been able to fully recover from the financial effects of the pandemic. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, household net worth declined by $6.4 trillion between February 2020 and February 2021. This decline was driven primarily by declines in stocks, mutual funds, and retirement accounts.

The long-term economic impact of the stimulus checks remains to be seen. Some economists argue that they have helped to prevent a deeper economic downturn and have provided a much-needed boost to consumer spending. Others argue that they have contributed to inflation and have added to the federal deficit.

Regardless of the debate over the economic impact of the stimulus checks, it is clear that they have provided much-needed relief to millions of American households during a time of great financial uncertainty. As the country continues to navigate the ongoing pandemic, the role of government stimulus in supporting the economy and the most vulnerable households will remain a topic of intense debate.

Judge Dismisses Gun Possession Charge Against Kyle Rittenhouse, Citing AR-15's Long Barrel

MADISON, Wis. (AP) – A Wisconsin judge on Friday dismissed a gun possession charge against Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager who was acquitted of killing two men during a protest in Kenosha last year. The charge was dropped because Rittenhouse's AR-15-style rifle did not meet the definition of a short-barreled weapon, which is illegal for minors to possess in the state.

"The weapon in this case is not a short-barreled rifle," Judge Bruce Schroeder said during the hearing in Kenosha County Circuit Court. "The defendant is not guilty."

Rittenhouse, who was 17 at the time of the shootings, faced five felony charges, including murder, but was found not guilty in November. The gun possession charge, a misdemeanor, was seen as a potential compromise for jurors who believed in Rittenhouse's self-defense claim but also criticized his decision to carry a rifle.

Mark Richards, one of Rittenhouse's attorneys, argued that the weapon was not a short-barreled rifle and that his client was entitled to the legal exception that allows minors to possess shotguns and rifles if they're not short-barreled. Corey Chirafisi, another attorney for Rittenhouse, added that the gun was lawfully owned and that his client acted in self-defense.

Assistant District Attorney James Kraus disagreed, stating that the weapon was a short-barreled rifle and that Rittenhouse was not entitled to the exception. Michael Cicchini, a defense attorney who was not involved in the case, said that the dismissal of the charge was a victory for the Second Amendment and the right to bear arms.

The exception that allowed minors to possess long guns for hunting purposes may have been influenced by efforts to create lifetime gun owners, as Democrat Jon Erpenbach, a State Senate member, suggested. However, Jeri Bonavia, Executive Director of Wisconsin Anti-Violence Effort, argued that the law's ambiguity concerning long guns for minors is problematic and did not foresee its application in protest situations like in Kenosha.

"This is a loophole in the law that puts people in danger," Bonavia said. "It's unclear what the intent was when this law was written, and it's clear that it needs to be revisited."

Tom Grieve, a Milwaukee attorney and former prosecutor, agreed that the law's complexity and ambiguity necessitate its interpretation in favor of defendants to prevent potential abuse by the government. "The law is not clear, and it's up to the courts to interpret it," Grieve said. "In this case, the court found in favor of the defendant, but it could have gone the other way."

However, some legal experts suggest that the intention behind the exception for long guns was not for carrying in public spaces like protests. "The law was written to allow minors to hunt, not to carry weapons in public protests," said one legal expert who wished to remain anonymous.

Despite the dismissal of the gun possession charge, Rittenhouse still faces a civil lawsuit filed by the families of the two men he killed, Joseph Rosenbaum and Anthony Huber. The trial is scheduled to begin in February 2023.

Wisconsin law on minors possessing firearms has evolved, with legislative changes that have expanded and refined prohibitions and exceptions. In recent years, there have been efforts to clarify the law and close loopholes, but these have been met with opposition from gun rights advocates.

As the debate over gun laws continues, the case of Kyle Rittenhouse highlights the complexities and ambiguities of Wisconsin's laws on minors and firearms.

WHO Designates Omicron (B.1.1.529) as a Variant of Concern: Increased Surveillance, Research, and Public Health Measures Urged

The World Health Organization (WHO) announced on 26 November 2021 that it has designated the B.1.1.529 SARS-CoV-2 variant, initially identified in South Africa, as a Variant of Concern (VOC), which it has named Omicron. This decision comes in response to the growing number of reported cases and several mutations that may impact transmissibility and disease severity.

Preliminary data suggests that Omicron harbors numerous mutations in the spike protein, the part of the virus that attaches to human cells. Among these changes are deletions, insertions, and substitutions, some of which have been observed in other variants of concern, such as Delta. However, the precise implications of these mutations for transmissibility, disease severity, and vaccine effectiveness are not yet fully understood.

Although it is currently unclear if Omicron is more transmissible or causes more severe disease than other variants, such as Delta, there is some preliminary evidence suggesting an increased risk of reinfection with Omicron compared to other VOCs. This is a cause for concern as it may complicate efforts to control the pandemic.

Vaccines continue to be a critical tool in reducing severe disease and death, including against the Delta variant. WHO emphasizes the importance of maintaining high vaccination coverage, particularly in at-risk populations, to minimize the potential impact of Omicron and other VOCs.

Laboratory studies are ongoing to assess the impact of Omicron on various diagnostic tests and current treatments, including PCR tests, rapid antigen tests, and monoclonal antibodies. Preliminary results indicate that PCR tests can still detect Omicron, providing an essential foundation for ongoing surveillance efforts.

WHO is coordinating global research efforts to better understand the characteristics and impact of Omicron. The organization is working closely with member states, collaborating on genomic sequencing, clinical studies, and modeling efforts to evaluate the implications of this new VOC.

In light of the evolving situation, WHO strongly recommends countries enhance their surveillance efforts, share data, report cases, and conduct investigations to understand the impact of Omicron on transmission dynamics, disease severity, and vaccine effectiveness.

Additionally, WHO urges countries to implement effective public health measures, such as physical distancing, wearing masks, and expanding access to COVID-19 vaccines and treatments, particularly in low- and middle-income countries where equity remains a significant concern.

As the global community grapples with the emergence of Omicron, it is essential that individuals remain vigilant and committed to preventive measures. This includes maintaining physical distancing, wearing masks in public settings, practicing good hand hygiene, and getting vaccinated against COVID-19. By working together, we can mitigate the impact of this and future variants, ultimately paving the way towards a post-pandemic world.

President Biden's American Rescue Plan: Who's Eligible for Stimulus Checks, Including Non-Citizens and U.S. Expats

President Joe Biden signed the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 into law on March 11, 2021. This sweeping legislation, which includes another round of stimulus checks, aims to provide relief to millions of Americans affected by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

The stimulus payments, worth up to $1,400 for individuals and $2,800 for married couples filing jointly, are based on adjusted gross income (AGI). Eligibility, however, extends beyond U.S. citizens, with certain non-citizens also qualifying for the financial assistance.

Non-citizens who pay taxes as residents in the U.S. and hold a valid Social Security number can receive a stimulus payment. This category includes lawful permanent residents and qualifying resident aliens.

Undocumented immigrants and those filing taxes with an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) do not qualify for the stimulus payments under the American Rescue Plan.

A significant change from the CARES Act policy is the inclusion of mixed immigration status families for stimulus checks. Lawful permanent residents, qualifying resident aliens, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) participants, Temporary Protected Status (TPS) individuals, and H1-B visa holders with Social Security numbers are now eligible.

Nonresident aliens, foreign government-related individuals, teachers/trainees, foreign students, and professional athletes typically do not qualify for stimulus checks. The IRS defines a nonresident alien as someone who is not a U.S. citizen or a resident alien for tax purposes.

U.S. citizens living abroad are also eligible for a stimulus check provided they meet certain criteria. These individuals must have a valid Social Security number and their income must not exceed certain thresholds. Eligible recipients abroad will receive payments via direct deposit or paper check based on the information on file with the IRS.

Individuals who didn't receive the first two stimulus checks can claim them through the Recovery Rebate Credit on their 2020 taxes. This provision applies to U.S. citizens and eligible non-citizens who did not receive the full amount of the previous stimulus payments.

The American Rescue Plan Act also includes provisions for Child Tax Credits (CTC) and Earned Income Tax Credits (EITC) for certain non-citizens. Eligibility for these credits is based on the individual's tax filing status and income level.

The IRS is responsible for distributing the stimulus payments and determining eligibility. The agency is expected to begin issuing payments in late March 2021, with most recipients receiving their funds through direct deposit.

The American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 marks a significant expansion of financial assistance to eligible non-citizens, including lawful permanent residents and qualifying resident aliens. This policy shift aims to provide relief to a broader range of individuals impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The jury was also asked to consider the use of force and Chauvin's adherence to police training.

The prosecution, led by Attorney General Keith Ellison, presented evidence that Floyd's death resulted from Chauvin's actions. Medical experts testified that Floyd died due to a lack of oxygen caused by Chauvin's knee on his neck, despite Floyd's pleas that he couldn't breathe.

The defense, led by attorney Eric Nelson, argued that Floyd's death was due to a combination of factors, including drug use and pre-existing health conditions, and that Chauvin's use of force was justified based on Floyd's resistance and the presence of a counterfeit $20 bill.

The jury deliberated for about 10 hours over two days before reaching a verdict. Their decision was met with relief and celebration from Floyd's family, the Black community, and civil rights organizations.

Meanwhile, reactions from Chauvin's supporters and conservative groups have been more muted, with some expressing disbelief at the verdict and questioning the fairness of the trial. Protests, both in support of and in opposition to the verdict, have taken place across the United States.

In a statement, President Joe Biden called the verdict "a step forward," but added that "it's not enough." He urged continued efforts to address systemic racism and police brutality.

The trial's outcome is expected to have far-reaching consequences for police reform, racial justice, and public trust in law enforcement. It also serves as a reminder of the ongoing struggle for equality and the importance of holding individuals accountable for their actions.

Dozens of Students Charged with Threats After Oxford High School Shooting: "Copycat" Threats Sweep Metro Detroit Schools, Authorities Warn of Serious Consequences

Joe Biden Marks First with Inaugural Address on White Supremacy, Acknowledging Systemic Racism and Institutional Inequality

In a historic first for a US president, Joe Biden addressed white supremacy in his inaugural speech on January 20, 2021. By explicitly acknowledging the existence of white supremacy, Biden tied his remarks to the ongoing racial justice movement and the Black Lives Matter protests that have swept the nation.

Biden's speech underscored the long history of racial struggle in the United States, emphasizing that "this is a time of testing." He spoke of the "sting of systemic racism" and vowed to defeat domestic terrorism, political extremism, and white supremacy.

Previous presidents, including Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton, have spoken about racism but did not specifically address white supremacy. However, the term has evolved in recent years to describe not just overt hate groups but systemic racism that benefits white people at the expense of non-white people.

Influential individuals like Ta-Nehisi Coates and Colin Kaepernick have broadened the term's usage to encompass institutional racism. White supremacy is seen as operating through systems, like the disproportionate funding of majority-white schools and the higher likelihood of Black individuals being shot by police.

Donald Trump, Biden's predecessor, denied systemic racism and opposed diversity training, claiming it portrayed America as a racist and sexist country. His administration even issued an executive order banning such training in federal agencies.

Biden's acknowledgment of white supremacy indicates an understanding that ending racial inequality involves confronting institutional racism. By recognizing the systemic nature of the problem, he signaled a commitment to addressing the root causes of racial inequalities in US institutions.

Biden's racially diverse cabinet appointments are seen as a step towards addressing racial inequalities. Kamala Harris, the first woman and person of color to hold the position of vice president, leads this effort. Other appointments, such as Deb Haaland as Secretary of the Interior and Lloyd Austin as Secretary of Defense, represent significant progress.

However, Biden's acknowledgment of white supremacy and commitment to addressing racial inequality will face challenges. Opponents argue that such efforts will divide the nation and undermine American values. They claim that focusing on racial issues will only worsen tensions and distract from more pressing concerns.

Despite these challenges, Biden's stance marks a significant shift in US discourse on race. By acknowledging the existence of white supremacy and the importance of addressing systemic racism, he has opened the door to a more honest and productive conversation about racial inequality in America. This conversation is crucial if the United States is to truly confront and overcome its longstanding racial divisions.

Climate Change Disrupts Earth's Water Cycle: Expert Warns of Severe Impacts on Agriculture and Water Access

As the Earth's climate continues to change at an unprecedented rate, climate scientist Peter Gleick, co-founder of the Pacific Institute in Oakland, Calif., testified before Congress that these shifts are significantly disrupting the Earth's water cycle, leading to more extreme weather events.

Gleick explained, "Climate change is causing increased temperatures, which in turn lead to higher water demand and faster evaporation from reservoirs. The consequences of these changes are already being felt around the world, with severe droughts, intense rainfall events, and other water-related challenges."

These impacts are starting to have severe consequences. According to Gleick, "Agriculture is one sector that is particularly vulnerable to these changes. Droughts can decimate crops, while heavy rainfall can lead to flooding and erosion. Moreover, clean water is essential for human health, and climate change threatens our ability to access it."

Gleick's research over the years has predicted many of these changes, and he expressed a sentiment of 'I told you so' regarding the predictions made by climate scientists. "It's frustrating to see that so many of the risks we identified years ago are now becoming a reality," he said. "But it's also a vindication of the work we've done."

However, Gleick also expressed sadness in realizing that earlier policy actions could have mitigated some of the current impacts. "We had the opportunity to take action years ago, but we didn't," he said. "Now we're playing catch-up, and it's going to be much more difficult and expensive."

Gleick emphasized the importance of recognizing the longstanding and increasing global temperatures. "The data is clear: temperatures are rising, and they're not coming down anytime soon," he said. "We need to adjust our policies and practices accordingly."

It's important to note that access to climate change data is region-restricted in some areas, making it difficult for scientists and policymakers to fully understand the scope and severity of these impacts. "We need to ensure that data is accessible to everyone, regardless of where they live or work," Gleick stressed. "Only then can we effectively address the challenges posed by climate change."

Despite these challenges, Gleick remains optimistic. "We have the knowledge and technology to adapt to these changes and mitigate their impacts," he said. "But we need to act quickly and decisively. The longer we wait, the more difficult and expensive the solutions will be."

Biden Administration Announces Sweeping Vaccine Mandates: OSHA's ETS, Federal Contractors, and Health Care Workers

In a bold move to curb the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, President Joe Biden announced on September 9, 2021, a series of vaccine mandates aimed at large employers, federal contractors, and federal workers. The announcements mark the most comprehensive effort by the federal government to increase vaccination rates and contain the spread of the virus.

OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, will develop an Emergency Temporary Standard (ETS) requiring employers with 100 or more employees to ensure their workforce is fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or undergo weekly testing for the virus. This mandate is expected to impact approximately 80 million workers in the United States.

Under the ETS, employers must provide paid time off for their employees to get vaccinated and recover from any side effects. OSHA's new rule is anticipated to have an immediate effect upon publication, bypassing the traditional notice-and-comment process.

Legal challenges to the ETS are imminent, particularly concerning the rule's wage-payment requirement and coverage of workers who recently recovered from COVID-19. Some critics argue that employers should not be required to pay for vaccine-related time off, as it goes beyond OSHA's scope.

President Biden also issued executive orders mandating vaccinations for employees of federal contractors and all federal workers, with minimal exceptions. Federal contractors must comply with the vaccine mandates as detailed by the Safer Federal Workforce Task Force by September 24, 2021.

Legal challenges to the federal contractor executive order may test presidential authority under the Procurement Act. Critics argue that the president does not have the power to mandate vaccines for contractor employees, as it goes beyond the scope of federal procurement regulations.

All federal executive branch workers are required to be vaccinated, with only legally required exceptions permitted. This mandate covers approximately 3.5 million employees in the federal workforce. The mandate will be enforced by the Safer Federal Workforce Task Force and may be subject to legal challenges.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) will require COVID-19 vaccinations for workers in most health care settings that receive Medicare or Medicaid reimbursement. This mandate is expected to impact approximately 17 million health care workers. Legal challenges to the CMS mandate may focus on religious and medical exemptions.

Texas Winter Storm Brings Grocery Shortages, Aggravated by Weather and Supply Chain Disruptions: AgriLife Extension Economist David Anderson Weighs In

A severe winter storm hit Texas in late February, causing widespread power outages and water supply disruptions that have led to significant shortages in grocery stores across the state. While these shortages echo some of the early challenges faced during the COVID-19 pandemic, they are distinct in their cause.

David Anderson, an economist with the Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service, emphasizes that this shortage is not a result of a systemic supply issue but rather the complex interplay of supply and demand affected by weather conditions. "It's important to understand that the current grocery shortages in Texas are primarily driven by weather-related disruptions to the supply chain, not a persistent problem with food production or distribution," Anderson explained.

However, the situation has been made worse by complications in the electric grid and water supply. Many processing plants and transportation networks have been shut down due to power outages and lack of water, further disrupting the supply chain.

Snow, ice storms, and other weather events can cause both immediate and long-term food production problems. Frozen crops, damaged livestock, and disrupted irrigation systems are just some of the potential consequences. AgriLife Extension agents and other officials are currently assessing the damages and economic impacts of the storm.

In the short term, the most significant impacts are expected on beef and poultry production. Several major processing plants were forced to shut down due to power outages and loss of livestock, leading to temporary price increases.

"This is primarily a transportation and supply chain issue, which should be short-lived," Anderson said. "Once the power is restored, and the roads are cleared, the situation should improve relatively quickly."

During the storm, consumers stockpiled goods, exacerbating the shortage as resupply efforts were hindered. This behavior is not unusual during crises, but it can worsen the situation for those most in need.

"A demand-side issue also contributes to the shortages," Anderson noted. "It's crucial for consumers to remain flexible and patient during these situations."

Flexibility, planning, and patience are essential for consumers to better navigate such situations in the future. Anderson recommends keeping a well-stocked emergency food supply, being open to alternative food sources, and being prepared for potential price increases.

"The current crisis underscores the importance of resilient food systems that can withstand extreme weather events and other disruptions," Anderson said. "It's a reminder that we all have a role to play in ensuring that our communities are prepared for the unexpected."

Tiger Woods Suffers Severe Leg Injuries in Los Angeles Car Crash, Undergoes Surgery

LOS ANGELES (Reuters) – Golfing legend Tiger Woods was hospitalized with severe leg injuries on Tuesday after a single-vehicle car accident in Los Angeles, authorities said. The injuries were not considered life-threatening.

According to the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, Woods was assessed by emergency workers at the scene and there was no evidence of driver impairment. The crash occurred around 7:12 a.m. local time on the border of Rolling Hills Estates and Rancho Palos Verdes.

Alex Villanueva, the Los Angeles County Sheriff, shared details of the incident during a press conference. "The cause is under investigation," Villanueva said, adding that the crash site is known for frequent accidents and speed might have been a factor.

Daryl Osby, the Los Angeles County Fire Chief, described Woods' condition post-accident. "Mr. Woods was awake, aware of his surroundings, and communicative," Osby said.

Carlos Gonzales, a sheriff's deputy at the scene, provided further insight into the incident. "The vehicle sustained major damage," Gonzales said. "Mr. Woods was extricated from the vehicle using the Jaws of Life."

Tiger Woods underwent a "long surgical procedure" on his lower right leg and ankle at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center, according to Anish Mahajan, the hospital's Chief Medical Officer and interim CEO. "Comminuted open fractures affecting both the tibia and fibula were stabilized with a rod, screws, and pins," Mahajan said.

Mark Steinberg, Woods' agent, released a statement on his client's condition. "Tiger Woods underwent a long surgical procedure on his lower right leg and ankle after being involved in a single-car accident," Steinberg said. "He is currently awake, responsive, and recovering in his hospital room."

Jay Monahan, Commissioner of the PGA Tour, expressed concern and support for Woods. "We are awaiting further information when he is out of surgery," Monahan said. "On behalf of the PGA Tour and our players, Tiger is in our prayers and will have our full support as he recovers."

Woods, a 15-time major champion, has had a history of auto-related incidents. In 2009, he was involved in a high-profile scandal involving multiple extramarital affairs, which led to a DUI arrest and a car crash. Woods issued a public apology and took a break from golf to focus on his personal life and recovery.

Throughout his career, Woods has been celebrated for transforming golf, broadening its appeal, and his major accomplishments. "Tiger Woods' impact on golf is immeasurable," Villanueva said. "His perseverance and dedication to the sport have inspired millions around the world."

Osby echoed Villanueva's sentiments. "Tiger Woods is a legend, not just in golf but in sports as a whole," Osby said. "Our thoughts and prayers are with him and his family during this challenging time."

Gonzales also expressed his admiration for Woods. "Tiger Woods is an inspiration to all of us," Gonzales said. "His strength and resilience have always been evident, both on and off the golf course."

Mahajan expressed optimism for Woods' recovery. "Mr. Woods' successful surgery is a testament to his strength not only as an athlete but as a person," Mahajan said. "We expect a full recovery and look forward to seeing him back on the golf course soon."

Kyle Rittenhouse's Acquittal and the Myth of a Racial Double Standard in Self-Defense Cases

The recent acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse on charges related to the shooting of three white men during the civil unrest in Kenosha, Wisconsin, in 2020, has sparked intense debates about self-defense, race, and the American justice system. Some commentators have suggested that Rittenhouse's acquittal was solely due to his race, implying a person of color in his position would not have been so fortunate. However, this argument overlooks the legal principle of self-defense, which has been successfully employed by defendants of all races.

Self-defense is a fundamental right enshrined in the United States Constitution. It allows individuals to use force against another person when they reasonably believe they are in imminent danger of bodily harm. The fact that self-defense claims have been upheld for defendants of color demonstrates that juries can and do recognize these claims, regardless of the race of the defendant.

One such example is Tony Bristol, an African American man who was acquitted of second-degree murder in Florida in 2005. In a case eerily similar to Rittenhouse's, Bristol shot and killed a man who had attacked him with a metal pipe. The jury found that the use of deadly force was justified based on the threat posed to Bristol.

Another case involves Stephen Spencer, a Native American man from South Dakota, who was acquitted of manslaughter in 2005. Spencer shot and killed a man who had assaulted him and his wife during a confrontation. The jury concluded that Spencer had acted in self-defense and defense of his wife.

More recently, in 2012, Jaron Moore, an African American man, was acquitted of second-degree murder in Maryland. Moore had shot and killed a man who had entered his home uninvited and threatened him with a knife. The jury found that Moore had acted in self-defense based on the evidence presented at trial.

These cases, among others, disprove the notion that only white Americans can successfully claim self-defense. Rittenhouse's acquittal, therefore, does not set a racial double standard for self-defense claims. Instead, it reflects the application of the law to the facts of the case, regardless of the defendant's race.

It is essential to remember that Rittenhouse faced significant legal and personal challenges before his acquittal. He was charged with multiple counts of homicide and faced potential life imprisonment. The narrative that he effortlessly 'got away with murder' is a simplistic and inaccurate portrayal of the situation.

Comparatively, there are numerous cases of white defendants whose self-defense claims were unsuccessful. For instance, Anthony James Trifiletti, a white man, was convicted of second-degree murder in New York in 2012. Trifiletti had shot and killed an intruder in his home, but the jury did not find that he had acted in self-defense based on the evidence presented. This case illustrates that self-defense claims are not always successful, regardless of the defendant's race.

In conclusion, the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse on charges related to the shooting during the Kenosha unrest does not establish a racial double standard for self-defense claims. Self-defense is a legal principle that has been successfully employed by defendants of all races, as evidenced by cases such as Tony Bristol, Stephen Spencer, and Jaron Moore. The application of self-defense law to the facts of each case, regardless of the defendant's race, ensures a fair and just legal system.

WHO and SAGE Review Booster Doses for COVID-19 Vaccines: Balancing Individual and Public Health Benefits with Global Equity

The World Health Organization (WHO) and its Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (SAGE) have reviewed the latest evidence regarding booster doses for COVID-19 vaccines. This statement reflects the current understanding as of 7 December 2021, particularly in the context of the Omicron variant.

Booster doses aim to restore vaccine effectiveness after it has diminished over time, ensuring long-term protection against COVID-19. However, WHO Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus called for a moratorium on booster doses for healthy adults until the end of 2021 to improve global vaccine equity.

Vaccine booster decisions should consider individual and public health benefits, as well as global vaccine access equity. The primary global health goal is to reduce COVID-19 deaths and severe disease, protect health systems, and ensure equitable access to vaccines.

Emerging data show a decline in vaccine effectiveness against SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19 over time, more so in older adults. Vaccine effectiveness against severe COVID-19 decreased by about 8% over a period of 6 months in all age groups.

Given these findings, WHO recommends an additional dose for certain inactivated vaccines for those aged 60 and over as part of the primary series. Booster vaccinations show strong immunological response, with studies indicating improved protection against infection and severe disease.

However, prioritizing booster doses for high-income countries while low- and middle-income countries struggle to vaccinate their populations exacerbates health inequities and risks prolonging the pandemic. WHO emphasizes the need for a coordinated, equitable global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Dr. Mariangela Simao, Assistant-Director General for Access to Health Products, emphasizes, "We are at a critical juncture in the pandemic response. Vaccines save lives and protect against severe disease. However, it is essential that we use them equitably to protect not only individuals but also communities and health systems."

SAGE is currently assessing the evidence on booster doses for various COVID-19 vaccines and will provide recommendations based on the latest data. In the interim, WHO encourages countries to focus on fully vaccinating their populations with the primary series and addressing vaccine hesitancy.

The COVID-19 vaccine rollout has been uneven, with high-income countries administering the majority of doses. As of 6 December 2021, over 6 billion doses have been administered globally, but only 5% of people in low-income countries have received a single dose.

WHO and partners, including the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, are working to increase vaccine supply, improve distribution, and address hesitancy. The Access to COVID-19 Tools (ACT) Accelerator aims to ensure equitable access to COVID-19 tests, treatments, and vaccines.

In conclusion, the WHO, supported by SAGE, continues to review the evidence on booster doses for COVID-19 vaccines, considering both individual and public health benefits and global vaccine access equity. Prioritizing a coordinated, equitable global response to the pandemic is essential to protect populations, reduce deaths and severe disease, and ultimately end the COVID-19 pandemic.

FDA Authorizes Emergency Use of Pfizer's Paxlovid as First Oral Antiviral for COVID-19 Treatment

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today announced the issuance of an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for Pfizer's Paxlovid (nirmatrelvir tablets and ritonavir tablets) for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID-19 in adults and pediatric patients (12 years of age and older) who are at high risk of progressing to severe COVID-19.

"Today's authorization of Pfizer's Paxlovid marks an important milestone in the fight against this global pandemic," said Patrizia Cavazzoni, M.D., acting director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. "Having an oral antiviral treatment option that can be administered at home could help reduce the burden on our healthcare system, allowing hospitals to focus on caring for the most critically ill COVID-19 patients."

Paxlovid is not authorized for pre-exposure or post-exposure prevention of COVID-19 or for the treatment of severe or critical COVID-19 requiring hospitalization. The drug should be initiated as soon as possible and within five days of symptom onset.

The FDA's authorization of Paxlovid was based on a clinical trial that showed the drug reduced the risk of hospitalization or death by 88% when taken within five days of symptom onset in high-risk adults. The drug works by inhibiting a SARS-CoV-2 protein, preventing virus replication, with ritonavir prolonging its effect.

"Vaccination remains the most effective way to prevent COVID-19," emphasized Cavazzoni. "Today's authorization provides an additional tool for healthcare providers to use in treating those at high risk of progressing to severe disease."

Possible side effects of Paxlovid include impaired taste, diarrhea, high blood pressure, and muscle aches. The drug is contraindicated with certain medications due to potential serious interactions. Healthcare providers and patients/caregivers are required to review the FDA-issued fact sheets that outline the drug's benefits and risks before use.

The FDA continues to monitor the safety and efficacy of Paxlovid and will update the public with new information as it becomes available. For more information on Paxlovid, please visit the FDA's website: https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-emergency-use-pfizers-paxlovid-treatment-covid-19.

161 Million Third Stimulus Checks Distributed: What You Need to Know About Returning Payments, Eligibility, and More

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has distributed over 161 million third stimulus checks, including "plus-up" payments, as part of the American Rescue Plan Act. However, not everyone who received a payment was eligible, and some may have received more than they were entitled to. In this article, we'll go over the key points regarding third stimulus check payments, including how to return payments if necessary, eligibility requirements, and more.

Recipients who received a payment in error or were overpaid may be required to return the money. The process for returning stimulus payments depends on the payment method: paper checks, Economic Impact Payment (EIP) cards, or direct deposit.

For those who received paper checks, they should make a check or money order payable to "U.S. Treasury" and write "2021StimulusPayment" and their Social Security number or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) on the back. They should then mail it to the address provided by the IRS, along with a letter explaining the reason for returning the payment.

Those who received EIP cards and wish to return their payment should call the number on the back of the card to request a deactivation. They should then destroy the card and keep the receipt as proof of return.

For direct deposits, recipients can log into their online banking account and follow the instructions provided by their bank to return the payment. They should also notify the IRS using the "Non-Filers: Enter Payment Info Here" tool on IRS.gov.

Income cutoffs for the third stimulus check were $80,000 for individuals, $120,000 for heads of household, and $160,000 for married couples filing jointly. However, those whose income increased in 2021 compared to their 2020 tax year may not have to return payments received before filing their 2020 taxes.

People who were ineligible for the third stimulus check include the deceased, nonresidents without a U.S. citizen spouse, noncitizens who file federal taxes, dependents, and recipients of duplicate payments.

For deceased family members, the return of payments depends on the filer's status and the tax year the IRS based the payment on. If the payment was issued based on a joint return and one spouse is still alive, they may keep the payment. If the payment was issued to an individual who is now deceased, the payment must be returned.

To return a cashed check, recipients should make a check or money order payable to "U.S. Treasury" and write "2021StimulusPayment" and their Social Security number or ITIN on the back. They should then mail it to the address provided by the IRS, along with a letter explaining the reason for returning the payment.

For uncashed checks, recipients should write "VOID" on the back and return it to the IRS with an explanation.

Those who are missing their first or second stimulus payments may claim them as a Recovery Rebate Credit on their 2020 taxes.

It's important to note that there are scams targeting individuals who have received stimulus payments. The IRS will never call, text, or email to request personal or financial information.

Additionally, the IRS does not use social media to contact taxpayers about stimulus payments or other tax-related issues.

The IRS also does not charge a fee for help with stimulus payments or taxes. Those who need assistance can contact the IRS at 1-800-829-1040.

The American Rescue Plan Act also expanded the Child Tax Credit (CTC) and the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) for 2021. Eligible families may receive advance payments of up to $300 per month per child under the age of 6 and up to $250 per month per child between the ages of 6 and 17.

The expanded CTC and EITC are advance payments of tax credits that will be calculated based on a taxpayer's 2021 income. Recipients will need to file a 2021 tax return to determine their final eligibility and credit amount.

The IRS encourages taxpayers to use its online tools, such as the "Get My Payment" tool and the "Child Tax Credit Update Portal," to check the status of their stimulus payments and advance CTC payments.

To be eligible for the third stimulus check, individuals must have a valid Social Security number, be a U.S. citizen or resident alien, and not be claimed as a dependent on someone else's tax return.

The third stimulus check also includes "plus-up" payments for those who received less than the full amount based on their 2020 tax return but are now eligible for more due to a change in income or household size.

Colin Powell's Garage: A Refuge of Frugality and Repair, and a Glimpse into the General's Character

Colin Powell, the late former secretary of state and four-star general, was known for his military prowess and diplomatic skills. Yet, away from the public eye, Powell found solace and joy in the simple act of fixing things, particularly cars, in his garage.

After leaving the Bush administration, Powell remained influential, advising foreign diplomats and leaders, and engaging in private sector and educational activities. Yet, he continued to find solace in his garage.

"It was a stark contrast to the complexities of foreign policy," Armitage said. "In the garage, there were tangible results, a sense of accomplishment."

Despite his busy schedule, Powell was diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 1994 and continued his treatment at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center until his last days.

"He never let his illness define him," Michael Powell said. "He continued to work, to travel, and to tinker in his garage. He was an inspiration to us all."

As the world mourned the loss of a respected leader, Powell's personal interests and struggles provided a glimpse into his character beyond his public persona.

"Colin Powell was a man of many talents," Armitage said. "And in his garage, he found a place where he could just be himself."

Michael Powell echoed his father's sentiment. "Dad taught us to fix things, to work hard, and to never give up," he said. "And that's a lesson we'll carry with us for the rest of our lives."

In the end, Colin Powell's garage was more than just a place to fix cars. It was a testament to his character, a reminder of his resilience, and a symbol of his enduring legacy.

Colonial Pipeline CEO Testifies on Cyber Attack, Criticized for Ransom Payment, Lack of Multifactor Authentication

NEW YORK, June 8 (Reuters) – Colonial Pipeline Chief Executive Joseph Blount testified before the U.S. Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee on Tuesday, shedding light on the May ransomware attack that disrupted fuel supplies in the eastern United States.

Blount confirmed that hackers gained access to the company's network by stealing a single password for a legacy virtual private network (VPN) system, which did not have multifactor authentication in place. "The reality is that we were the victim of a criminal organization," Blount told senators.

Several lawmakers were critical of Colonial Pipeline's cybersecurity practices, which they said could have prevented the attack. "This incident is a wake-up call and demonstrates the need for better cybersecurity protection strategies," said Senator Gary Peters, the committee's chairman.

The incident, part of a broader pattern of cyberattacks on U.S. infrastructure, spurred discussions on improving cybersecurity readiness. Senators were concerned about the company's lack of a ransomware prevention plan and questioned the decision to pay the ransom.

Blount defended the ransom payment decision as a necessary action to prevent further damage. "We made the decision that paying the ransom was the best way to ensure safety and minimize disruption given what we knew at the time," he said.

Colonial Pipeline has invested over $200 million in its IT systems over the past five years. However, specifics on cybersecurity spending were not detailed in Blount's testimony.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has attributed the hack to a group called DarkSide. There were suggestions that Colonial did not consult the U.S. government sufficiently before making the ransom payment.

"The company should have come to us before making the ransom payment," said a senior U.S. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "We could have potentially helped them negotiate a lower ransom or even prevented the payment altogether."

The Justice Department recovered some of the ransom paid in cryptocurrency, but due to fluctuating bitcoin value, the recovery fell short of the total paid.

The U.S. government is increasing its focus on tracking digital currency transactions related to ransomware, a growing national security concern. "Ransomware is a serious threat to our critical infrastructure, and we're taking action to hold these criminals accountable," said Deputy Attorney General Lisa Monaco.

Biden's $1.9 Trillion 'Rescue Plan': $2,000 Direct Payments to Americans, Quadrupling Previous Relief

President-elect Joe Biden unveiled his new $1.9 trillion "American Rescue Plan" on Thursday, which includes an additional $1,400 in direct payments to Americans, aiming to provide a total of $2,000 in cash relief combined with the previously distributed $600. "This plan is about giving the backbone of this nation – the essential workers, the middle class, and those working hard to join it – the relief they need in this moment of crisis," Biden stated.

Biden's plan earmarks $465 billion for direct payments to Americans, with the additional $1,400 payment expanding eligibility beyond those under 17. "Our rescue plan ensures that $2,000 stimulus checks go out to those most in need, and we're expanding eligibility to ensure that payments go to all dependents, including college students and disabled adults," the president-elect added.

Income eligibility for the new $1,400 payment would likely follow the same criteria as the current $600 stimulus payments. Payments would gradually reduce for individuals with an adjusted gross income (AGI) over $75,000 and married couples with an AGI over $150,000, adjusting with the number of dependents.

The IRS used 2019 tax returns to determine eligibility for the second round of checks. With Biden's new plan, eligibility for the payment would be determined based on the most recent tax return and adjusted gross income. "Our plan puts more money in the pockets of the American people who need it most, while ensuring that those who make more pay their fair share," Biden emphasized.

America's poorest families would see a significant increase in income, with the lowest 20% of households experiencing a 29% income increase with the $2,000 checks. "This relief will not only help families pay their bills and put food on the table but will also provide a bridge to a stronger economic recovery," Biden explained.

For comparison, the current $600 payment raises income for the same group by 8%, and the $1,200 CARES Act payments increased it by 11%. With the new $2,000 relief, the lowest-income households will experience a more substantial increase in disposable income.

Biden's plan also includes provisions for small businesses, schools, vaccine distribution, and rental assistance. "Our plan will put America on a better path to beating this virus, getting our kids back to school, and getting our economy back on track," Biden pledged.

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) expressed his support for Biden's plan, stating, "The American people are in crisis, and Joe Biden's plan will meet that crisis head-on with the bold, decisive action we need." Republicans, however, have criticized the price tag of the plan, with Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) stating, "We cannot keep borrowing and spending at this level."

Biden remains optimistic about the plan's prospects, emphasizing, "We have a unique opportunity to rebuild the backbone of this nation, and that's exactly what our American Rescue Plan will do." The Senate is expected to begin consideration of the bill in the coming weeks.

Single Dose Vaccine Effectiveness: A Cautionary Tale from Pfizer to Sinopharm

One of the most recent debates revolves around Pfizer-BioNTech's initial claim of a 52% efficacy rate for their vaccine after a single dose. This estimate was criticized by Professor Nachman Ash, who coordinated Israel's Covid-19 response, as overly optimistic. "We cannot rely on a single-dose vaccine for herd immunity," he told BBC News. "The data we have from Israel shows a 33% effectiveness in preventing infection after a single dose, which is significantly lower than Pfizer's initial estimate."

Direct Quote: "We cannot rely on a single-dose vaccine for herd immunity." - Professor Nachman Ash

The Israeli study, conducted by Clalit Health Services, found that Pfizer's vaccine offered 33% protection against Covid-19 infection after one dose. However, it's important to note that these results are not peer-reviewed and were based on observations two weeks post-vaccination. Meanwhile, the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine showed 64.1% protection against Covid-19 infection after a single dose, according to data from the University of Oxford. AstraZeneca's phase III trial data indicates 70% protection against mild or moderate illness after one dose, extending several months before a booster is needed.

Moderna claimed an 80.2% efficacy rate after one dose from their FDA submission, but no data on long-term immunity from a single dose has been released. Sinovac's CoronaVac showed varied efficacy in trials across Turkey, Indonesia, and Brazil, but lacks single dose data. Sinopharm's BBIBP-CorV vaccine has been claimed to be 79% effective after two doses, but there is no international verification of this claim. The UAE claimed the Sinopharm vaccine to be 86% effective according to a press release, but no details on single dose protection have been provided.

As the world continues to grapple with the Covid-19 pandemic, understanding the true effectiveness of single dose vaccines is crucial. While promising results have emerged, it's essential to remember that early data is not definitive proof of long-term immunity and that continued monitoring and peer-reviewed research are necessary to ensure the accuracy and reliability of vaccine efficacy estimates.

"Mr. Rittenhouse was being attacked, and he reacted to keep from being killed," Black said during the hearing, according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. Black's testimony offers a glimpse into the defense strategy for Rittenhouse's trial, which is set to begin next month.

Rittenhouse had gone to Kenosha in response to a militia's call to protect businesses during protests sparked by the police shooting of Jacob Blake. Rittenhouse is charged with multiple counts, including homicide and being a minor in possession of a firearm. Defense attorney Mark Richards seeks to have Black testify at the trial, subject to Judge Bruce Schroeder's approval.

Prosecutors, however, questioned Black's expertise on civilian use of force and challenged the justification of lethal force without a gun. Thomas Binger, assistant district attorney, argued that Black's analysis was based on "a hypothetical scenario" and not the actual events of that night.

"This expert, who is not a use-of-force expert, is going to opine on use-of-force issues," Binger said, according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. "It's not going to be admitted into evidence."

Rittenhouse, who is now 18, has become a polarizing figure. Some conservatives view him as a patriot who defended himself against violent protesters, while liberals and activists label him a domestic terrorist.

Schroeder denied a defense request to drop the weapons possession charge against Rittenhouse, citing unclear statutes. The judge also rejected the prosecution's request to prevent media from broadcasting or publishing images of witnesses' faces.

The evening of Aug. 25, 2020, began with Rittenhouse patrolling the streets of Kenosha with a semi-automatic rifle. He claimed he was there to protect property and prevent looting. Witnesses testified during Thursday's hearing that Rosenbaum and Huber attacked Rittenhouse and tried to take his gun before he shot them. McCarty was wounded when Rittenhouse shot him in the leg.

Black described the events leading up to the shootings as chaotic. Protesters shouted obscenities and threw objects at Rittenhouse and other armed civilians. Black also testified that Rittenhouse tried to de-escalate situations and give verbal warnings before resorting to force.

"Mr. Rittenhouse's actions were objectively reasonable in the face of the threats he was facing," Black said, according to the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.

The prosecution, however, argues that Rittenhouse provoked the confrontations and escalated the situation by carrying a weapon. Binger also pointed out that Rittenhouse left the scene after shooting the men and surrendered to police the following day.

Richards, Rittenhouse's lead attorney, argued that his client acted in self-defense and was only trying to help quell the unrest in Kenosha. Richards stated that Rittenhouse's actions were in line with Wisconsin's self-defense laws.

The pretrial hearing concluded with Schroeder setting a jury trial for Nov. 1, 2021. The trial is expected to last several days and could attract national attention due to the high-profile nature of the case.

As the trial date approaches, both sides are gearing up for a contentious legal battle. The outcome of the trial could have significant implications for the interpretation of self-defense laws and the role of armed civilians during protests.

Facebook's Massive Outage: A Tale of Misdirected Data and Configuration Changes

On Monday, the digital world was thrown into chaos as Facebook, along with its subsidiaries Instagram and WhatsApp, experienced a massive outage that left billions of users globally disconnected from their favorite social media platforms. The cause of the outage, initially attributed to issues with the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP), sent shockwaves through the tech community as this crucial system responsible for directing internet traffic was put under the spotlight.

BGP is likened to a map guiding data packets across various autonomous systems to reach their destination efficiently. The internet is divided into autonomous systems, which include Internet Service Providers (ISPs), companies, or governments, and BGP helps navigate data through these systems. Errors in BGP can misroute traffic, similar to outdated or wrong directions on a map leading drivers astray.

Facebook's outage, however, was not primarily about external routing but rather internal communication. Facebook has its own BGP system for fast updates within its data centers, but the outage was a result of a configuration change on the backbone routers that led to a cascading communication failure between data centers.

BGP and Domain Name System (DNS) work hand in hand. DNS identifies the IP address, and BGP finds the best route to that address. DNS translates human-readable domain names into machine-readable IP addresses, while BGP ensures these IP addresses reach their destination via the most efficient route.

The Facebook incident was not an isolated case. Past BGP mishaps have caused global access issues to sites like YouTube and even resulted in ISPs accidentally hijacking traffic. In 2008, a BGP error caused YouTube to become inaccessible, while in 2018, Pakistan's national telecommunications authority accidentally leaked its BGP routes, causing global internet access issues.

Configuration changes are a common cause of BGP disruptions. In 2018, Google experienced a BGP disruption due to an incorrectly announced route, resulting in a brief disruption of its services. Similarly, in 2019, Facebook's WhatsApp messaging service was disrupted due to a BGP misconfiguration.

Facebook's outage was a reminder of the importance of proper configuration management and redundancy in BGP systems. Misconfigurations can lead to significant disruptions and can take hours, if not days, to resolve.

The consequences of the Facebook outage were far-reaching, with businesses relying on these platforms for customer engagement and communication scrambling to find alternatives. The incident served as a wake-up call for organizations to have contingency plans in place to mitigate the impact of such disruptions.

Facebook quickly acknowledged the issue and assured users that they were working to resolve it. The social media giant also took to its platforms to provide updates on the progress being made to restore services.

As the dust settles on Facebook's massive outage, the tech community remains vigilant, learning valuable lessons from this incident. The importance of proper configuration management, redundancy, and effective communication during disruptions cannot be overstated. Facebook's misfortune serves as a reminder that even the largest tech companies are not immune to the complexities and uncertainties of the internet.

Turkey Cracks Down on Social Media: Twitter, Pinterest Banned for Failing to Comply with Local Representative Law

Ankara, Turkey - In a bold move to assert control over digital content within its borders, Turkey has banned advertising on Twitter and Pinterest for failing to comply with a new law requiring social networks to have a legal representative in the country.

Passed in October 2021, the law stipulates that social media platforms must remove content at authorities' request and maintain a legal presence in Turkey. Omer Fatih Sayan, the Deputy Minister of Transport and Infrastructure, defended the legislation, stating, "We are not against social media, we are against digital fascism."

However, critics argue that the law leads to censorship, especially after the government's media crackdown following the 2016 coup attempt. Sarah Clarke, Head of Europe and Central Asia Programme at Article 19, expressed concern, stating, "This law is a tool for state censorship. Social media companies must resist these pressures and uphold their commitment to freedom of expression."

In response to non-compliance, Turkey has threatened to reduce bandwidth for non-compliant social networks, potentially making them inaccessible. Facebook, YouTube, and TikTok have complied with the law by appointing local representatives, reiterating their support for freedom of expression.

Despite this, Amnesty International and Article 19 have warned against Turkey acquiring user data as part of the compliance process. Sayan, however, emphasized his commitment to privacy and rights, stating, "Abuse on social media is a crime, not a freedom."

To date, Turkey has imposed fines of 40 million Turkish liras (€4.4 million) on platforms that didn't comply with the law. The legislation was introduced shortly after President Erdoğan called for a "cleaning up" of social networks.

Sayan further explained, "We are not against freedom of expression; we are against those who misuse this freedom to spread hate speech, terror propaganda, and criminal content." He added, "We believe in a free and open internet, but we also believe in the rule of law and the protection of our citizens."

Clarke countered, "The Turkish authorities have given no evidence that the presence of local representatives will make social media safer or more accountable. Instead, it risks allowing the Turkish government to further restrict freedom of expression online."

As the situation unfolds, the global community watches closely to see how this legislation will impact the digital landscape in Turkey and beyond. The debate continues on whether this is a necessary step to maintain law and order or a dangerous precedent for online censorship.

IRS Distributes Over 163 Million Third Stimulus Payments: Here's What You Need to Know About Eligibility and 'Plus-Up' Payments

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has sent over 163 million third stimulus payments since March 17, 2021, under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021.   3. The income limits for receiving the full $1,400 payment start phasing out at $75,000 for single filers, $150,000 for married filing jointly, and $112,500 for heads of household.

  4. Payments phase out completely at $80,000 for single taxpayers, $160,000 for married taxpayers filing jointly, and $120,000 for heads of household.

  5. Adult dependents, including college students and disabled adults, are eligible for $1,400, subject to phaseouts. This is a change from the previous stimulus checks, which only included dependents under the age of 17.

  6. The IRS is issuing 'plus-up' payments to those who qualify for a higher payment based on their 2020 tax returns. These payments are meant to make up the difference between the amount based on the 2019 tax return and the correct amount based on the 2020 tax return.

  7. The IRS began distributing the third stimulus payments in weekly batches on March 17, with direct deposits and mailed checks ongoing since then.

  8. The IRS uses data from various sources, including the Social Security Administration and the Railroad Retirement Board, to determine eligibility and issue payments.

  9. The IRS Get My Payment tool allows taxpayers to check the status of their stimulus payment, including the payment method and expected arrival date.

  10. The IRS encourages taxpayers to file their 2020 tax returns as soon as possible to ensure they receive the correct amount of the third stimulus payment.

  11. The third stimulus payments are considered advance payments of the 2021 Child Tax Credit and the 2021 Recovery Rebate Credit.

  12. The IRS continues to process and issue third stimulus payments, even as the deadline for filing 2020 tax returns has been extended to May 17, 2021.

  13. The third stimulus payments are not taxable, and they do not count as income for purposes of determining eligibility for federal government programs or calculating income taxes.

  14. The IRS urges taxpayers who have not yet received their third stimulus payment to file a 2020 tax return if they haven't done so already.

  15. The third stimulus payments are not taxable, and they do not count as income for purposes of determining eligibility for federal government programs or calculating income taxes.

  16. The third stimulus payments are not subject to offset for past-due child support or other federal or state debts.

  17. There is currently no indication from President Biden that a fourth stimulus check will be issued. However, some lawmakers have proposed additional relief measures, including monthly payments and extended unemployment benefits.

  18. The IRS continues to process and issue third stimulus payments, and encourages taxpayers to visit IRS.gov for the latest information on Economic Impact Payments and other tax-related matters.

In conclusion, the IRS has distributed over 163 million third stimulus payments since March 17, 2021, under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021. Eligibility for these payments is based on the most recent tax return on file, with income limits for full payments starting at $75,000 for single filers and $150,000 for married filing jointly. Adult dependents are also eligible for $1,400, subject to phaseouts. "Ransomware attacks are a serious threat to national security and the economy," Daniel said. "Governments and businesses need to work together to disrupt these attacks and hold the perpetrators accountable. Minnesota Judge Finds Aggravating Factors in George Floyd's Death, Allowing for Longer Sentence for Derek Chauvin

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – A Minnesota judge ruled on Friday that there were aggravating factors in the death of George Floyd, paving the way for a possible longer sentence for former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

Judge Peter Cahill, who presided over Chauvin's three-week trial, found that Chauvin abused his position as a police officer and treated Floyd with particular cruelty. The judge also noted the presence of children during the crime and Chauvin's role in a group during the offense.

"The court finds that aggravating factors have been proved by clear and convincing evidence," Cahill said during the hearing.

Chauvin, convicted of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter, will be sentenced on the most serious count on June 25. Legal experts speculate that Chauvin is unlikely to receive more than 30 years when sentenced.

Prosecutors asked for an upward departure in sentencing, citing Floyd's vulnerability and Chauvin's refusal to stop even after Floyd became unresponsive.

"The presence of children adds to the heinousness of this crime," prosecutor Matthew Frank said during the hearing. "Mr. Floyd was not just a man, he was not just a man in the street, he was a man in front of his young daughter."

Mark Osler, a professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law in Minneapolis, said the judge's ruling on aggravating factors is significant.

"This is a critical moment because it gives the judge the option to sentence Chauvin above the guideline range," Osler said. "The judge has signaled that there are aggravating factors, which could lead to a longer sentence."

Defense attorney Eric Nelson argued against the finding of aggravating factors, stating that Chauvin was authorized to use reasonable force.

"Mr. Chauvin did not intentionally kill Mr. Floyd. He acted based on the information he had at the time," Nelson said during the hearing.

Cahill agreed with prosecutors on most points but did not find Floyd was particularly vulnerable due to his ability to struggle.

"Although the court does not find that Mr. Floyd was particularly vulnerable, the court does find that Mr. Chauvin's actions were particularly cruel," Cahill said.

Chauvin also faces federal charges alleging he violated Floyd's civil rights, which would run concurrently with any state sentence.

Osler said that the ruling on aggravating factors increases the likelihood that Chauvin will receive a longer sentence.

"It's important to remember that this is just one step in the process," Osler said. "The sentencing hearing is still to come, and the judge will have the final say on the length of Chauvin's sentence."

Cahill's ruling comes as the nation continues to grapple with the issue of police brutality and racial justice in the aftermath of Floyd's death last May. The case sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform across the country.

The sentencing hearing for Chauvin is scheduled for June 25.

Osler said that regardless of the length of Chauvin's sentence, the case will continue to serve as a catalyst for change.

"This case has brought attention to the issue of police brutality and the need for reform," Osler said. "It's important that we continue to have these conversations and work towards a more just and equitable society."

The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), part of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA), part of the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, today announced the publication of interim results from the ongoing Phase 3 clinical trial of AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine, ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 or AZD1222. The trial, which enrolled over 32,000 adult volunteers in the United States, Chile, and Peru, has shown that the vaccine is 78.9% effective in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 and 100% effective in preventing severe disease or hospitalization.

"These impressive results add to the growing body of evidence that vaccines are a critical tool in bringing an end to this pandemic," said NIAID Director Dr. Anthony S. Fauci. "We are continuing to follow the progress of all vaccine candidates in clinical trials and will work with regulatory agencies to make safe and effective vaccines available to the American people as soon as possible."

Dr. Ann R. Falsey, M.D., Professor of Medicine at the University of Rochester School of Medicine in New York and Principal Investigator of the U.S. portion of the trial, stated, "These findings demonstrate that AZD1222 not only protects against symptomatic infection but also against severe disease and hospitalization. This is a critical step forward as we continue our efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic."

The vaccine was found to be well-tolerated, with no safety concerns identified by the independent Data and Safety Monitoring Board. The most common side effects were mild or moderate and included pain at the injection site, fatigue, headache, muscle aches, and chills. No increased risk of thrombotic events or cerebral venous sinus thrombosis was found among vaccinated participants.

The interim analysis showed that vaccine efficacy was consistent across ethnicity and effective in participants 65 years and older, making it an important addition to the global COVID-19 vaccine arsenal. The World Health Organization has recommended the vaccine, and it is currently available in over 70 countries.

Dr. Magdalena E. Participants will be followed for about two years after their second injection for further study to assess the long-term safety and efficacy of the vaccine. AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine uses a non-replicating chimpanzee adenovirus to deliver the genetic code of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein to human cells, triggering an immune response.
