These actions include issuing emergency use authorizations (EUAs) for antigen and molecular tests, establishing a Policy for Diagnostic Tests for Coronavirus Disease-2019 during the Public Health Emergency, and issuing EUAs for at-home collection kits.

Serial screening involves testing individuals on a regular basis, such as weekly or biweekly, to identify asymptomatic cases and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

"The FDA's actions today offer several options for accurate and reliable screening tests to help control the spread of COVID-19," Dr. Shuren concluded. "We will continue to work with test developers and other stakeholders to facilitate the development and authorization of COVID-19 tests that meet the public health needs of the nation."

The FDA, an agency within the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, protects the public health by assuring the safety, effectiveness, and security of human and veterinary drugs, vaccines and other biological products for human use, and medical devices. Most firearms used on film sets are real and require extensive paperwork, permits, and monitoring. They are often rented from licensed firearms dealers or private collectors and must undergo a thorough inspection before being allowed on set.

"When we receive a firearm, we first check its condition and ensure it's in good working order," explains Dillon. "We also make sure it has the proper paperwork and that it's registered with the production."

Revolvers and blank rounds are a common sight on movie sets. Blank rounds, also known as dummy rounds, are specifically designed for use in firearms during filming. These rounds do not contain gunpowder and are used to simulate the sound and recoil of a real gunshot.

Dillon elaborates on the use of revolvers and blank rounds: "When using a revolver on set, we always check the cylinder to ensure it's empty. We also use dummy rounds, which are specially designed not to fire but still provide the sound and feel of a real gunshot."

Safety measures on set include actor training, rehearsals with "cold" guns, checking for obstructions in the gun barrel, and using protective gear. Actor training is essential, as they must learn how to handle firearms safely and react appropriately during filming.

"Rehearsals with cold guns are a crucial part of the process," emphasizes Dillon. "Cold guns are unloaded weapons that are used for rehearsals and to familiarize the cast and crew with the firearms."

Safety officers and gun wranglers are always present on set to monitor firearms and ensure safety protocols are followed. They are responsible for checking each firearm before it's used and ensuring that all crew members are wearing appropriate protective gear.

Live rounds are generally prohibited on set, with the exception of certain educational scenarios, such as historical reenactments or military training films.

When live firing is necessary on set, specific protocols are observed, including checking if the chambers are empty and declaring the gun 'hot' before use.

"Live firing is a rare occurrence on a film set," says Dillon. "We only do it when it's absolutely necessary and when all safety protocols have been followed."

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) estimates that 720,000 more people could gain Medicaid postpartum coverage if all states extend coverage to a full year.

The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) have proposed a new "Birthing-Friendly" hospital designation and issued guidance for year-long Medicaid postpartum coverage. The Biden-Harris Administration is emphasizing addressing maternal health as a key priority, acknowledging the significant disparity among Black women and Native American women.

The Administration marks the first-ever White House Maternal Health Day of Action and announces new commitments under the Build Back Better Act. This legislation proposes a $3 billion investment in maternal health, including improvements in workforce diversity, data collection, social factors, substance use disorders, research, coverage, and care coordination.

States are encouraged to expand Medicaid coverage to 12 months postpartum, a significant increase from the current 60 days. A new HHS report shows the benefits of extending Medicaid postpartum coverage to a full year, including improved health outcomes for mothers and infants, reduced healthcare costs, and increased economic stability for families.

The United States has the highest maternal mortality rate among wealthy nations, worsening over the past 20 years, particularly for Black and Native American women. Vice President Harris has historically advocated for improved maternal health through legislation like the Maternal CARE Act and the Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act.

The Maternal CARE Act, introduced in 2019, aimed to address maternal mortality and morbidity by increasing research, improving data collection, and addressing social determinants of health. The Black Maternal Health Momnibus Act, introduced in 2021, focuses on addressing racial and ethnic disparities in maternal health.

The Biden-Harris Administration is committed to addressing the root causes of maternal health disparities and improving outcomes for all mothers. Through this Call to Action, the Administration aims to raise awareness, engage stakeholders, and encourage action to improve maternal health and reduce mortality and morbidity in the United States.

Tiger Woods' Crash: L.A. County Sheriff's Department Seeks Black Box Data, No Warrant for Blood

The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department obtained a search warrant for the black box from Tiger Woods' crashed car, but there is no plan to seek a warrant for the golfer's blood to determine if he was under the influence at the time of the accident, Sheriff's Deputy John Schloegl confirmed to USA TODAY.

Schloegl emphasized that the investigation is part of a routine probe and does not necessarily indicate a criminal investigation. "We're looking at the data from the car's event data recorder, or black box, which could provide valuable information regarding the vehicle's speed, steering, brake application, and acceleration before the crash," he explained.

According to Schloegl, a warrant for the black box requires probable cause that a crime was committed, which is not necessarily the case here. "We're focusing on the facts and gathering as much evidence as possible to piece together what happened," he added.

Jonathan Cherney, an accident reconstruction expert and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, suggested that Woods may not have been paying attention or could have even been asleep at the wheel based on early reports and the location of the crash scene. "It's not uncommon for drivers, especially older ones, to fall asleep at the wheel, especially if they have a condition like sleep apnea," he said.

Sheriff Alex Villanueva initially called the crash "purely an accident," but the department has not yet concluded the cause. "We're still in the process of gathering evidence and conducting interviews," Villanueva told USA TODAY. "It's too early to make any definitive statements about the cause of the crash."

In 2017, Woods was found asleep at the wheel with various medications in his system, but no evidence of impairment was observed at the scene. This time around, there's no indication that drugs or alcohol played a role in the crash.

Genesis, the car's manufacturer, has taken possession of the vehicle after the sheriff's department completed its examination. The automaker will use its own team of experts to analyze the data from the black box.

Schloegl declined to comment on any potential violations of traffic laws that might have contributed to the crash. "We're focusing on the facts and gathering as much evidence as possible to piece together what happened," he reiterated.

Cherney noted that there are several factors that could have contributed to the crash, including driver error, vehicle malfunction, and environmental conditions. "We won't know for sure until we have all the data and have had a chance to analyze it," he said.

Woods, who was not wearing a seatbelt at the time of the crash, was transported to the hospital with injuries to his right leg. The golfing legend underwent surgery on Tuesday and is expected to make a full recovery.

Villanueva expressed concern for Woods' wellbeing and wished him a speedy recovery. "Our thoughts are with Tiger and his family during this difficult time," he said.

Schloegl urged the public to be patient as the investigation unfolds. "We're committed to finding the truth and will release information as it becomes available," he promised.

In the meantime, Woods' fans and the golfing community are rallying around the iconic golfer, offering their support and well wishes for a swift recovery. "Tiger is a true legend, and we're all pulling for him," Cherney said. "He's been through a lot in his career, and I have no doubt he'll come back stronger than ever."

As the investigation into the cause of the crash continues, one thing is certain: Tiger Woods remains an inspiration to millions around the world, and his resilience in the face of adversity is a testament to his strength and determination.

President Biden Announces Comprehensive Strategy to Combat COVID-19, Boosting Vaccine Supply and Funding

Today, President Joe Biden announced a comprehensive strategy to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on increasing vaccine supply and funding to states, Tribes, and territories. In a press conference at the White House, the President outlined several key initiatives aimed at expediting the vaccination process and addressing the ongoing public health crisis.

Beginning this week, states, Tribes, and territories will see a 5 percent increase in vaccine supply, totaling 13.5 million doses. The President's goal is to administer 100 million vaccine shots in 100 days. To achieve this, vaccine supply to these entities will rise to 10.5 million doses weekly, a 22 percent increase since January 20. The Administration intends to maintain this increased supply for at least the next three weeks.

"Getting the vaccine into the arms of the American people is my top priority," said President Biden. "With these significant increases in vaccine supply, I am confident we can meet our goal of administering 100 million shots in 100 days."

In addition to increasing vaccine supply, the Federal Retail Pharmacy Program for COVID-19 Vaccination will launch on February 11. This program offers vaccines through select pharmacies, with 21 national pharmacy partners and networks representing over 40,000 locations participating. Priority groups will receive vaccinations at no cost in the initial phase, with limited supply.

"The Federal Retail Pharmacy Program is an essential part of our efforts to expand vaccine distribution and make it more convenient for Americans to get vaccinated," said President Biden. "By working together with pharmacies, we can help protect the health and safety of communities across the country."

President Biden also directed FEMA to fully reimburse states for COVID-related National Guard personnel and emergency costs retroactively from the beginning of the pandemic. The Administration estimates retroactive FEMA reimbursements to total $3-5 billion and has requested $350 billion from Congress in the American Rescue Plan to support these efforts and address ongoing pandemic-related needs.

"These actions demonstrate our commitment to doing everything in our power to combat this pandemic and support the American people," said President Biden. "We will not rest until this crisis is under control, and we can all begin to return to normalcy. Together, we will overcome this challenge and emerge stronger than ever before."

WHO Emergency Committee: Ongoing Challenges of COVID-19 Pandemic Require Risk-Based Vaccination Approach and Equity, Ethics, and Public Health Measures

The ninth meeting of the World Health Organization (WHO) Emergency Committee on COVID-19 took place on 22 October 2021. The Committee, consisting of international experts in various fields, convened to discuss the ongoing challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and provide recommendations to WHO Member States.

Professor Didier Houssin, Chair of the WHO Emergency Committee, opened the meeting by emphasizing the importance of a risk-based vaccination approach to effectively combat the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. "The pandemic is far from over, and we must continue to use all available tools to control its spread," Professor Houssin stated.

Committee members were briefed on ethics and conflict of interest related to COVID-19 vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics. "Ensuring transparency and trust in the development and distribution of these critical tools is essential," noted Professor Houssin.

Global epidemiological updates were discussed, focusing on the current state of the pandemic and the impact of various mitigation measures. "While some regions have seen a decrease in cases, others continue to experience significant surges," Professor Houssin noted.

Vaccine equity issues were raised during the meeting. "The inequitable distribution of vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics is a major concern, particularly in the African Region," Professor Houssin expressed.

The importance of maintaining public health and social measures (PHSM) alongside vaccinations was underlined. "Vaccines are an essential tool in our fight against COVID-19, but they are not a silver bullet," Professor Houssin stated. "PHSM remain crucial in preventing the further spread of the virus."

Research needs on various aspects of SARS-CoV-2 and pandemic response were identified. "We must continue to invest in research to better understand the virus and the most effective ways to control its spread," Professor Houssin emphasized.

The COVID-19 pandemic still constitutes a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). "The continued existence of this PHEIC underscores the need for a collaborative and coordinated global response," Professor Houssin stated.

The Committee's advice was unanimously agreed upon by the Director-General of WHO, who issued Temporary Recommendations to States Parties. "These recommendations emphasize the importance of a risk-based vaccination approach, equity, ethics, and the continued use of public health and social measures," Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated.

Dr. Tedros reiterated the call for increased vaccine equity and access to essential COVID-19 tools. "We cannot allow the unequal distribution of vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics to perpetuate this pandemic," Dr. Tedros expressed.

The Director-General concluded by reaffirming WHO's commitment to supporting Member States in their efforts to control the COVID-19 pandemic. "Together, we can turn the tide on this pandemic and ensure a healthier, more equitable future for all," Dr. Tedros stated.

Twitter Permanently Bans @realDonaldTrump Account After Pro-Trump Riot at Capitol

WASHINGTON (AP) – In a historic move, Twitter permanently suspended the account of former President Donald Trump on Friday, citing concerns of further incitement of violence following a pro-Trump mob's assault on the U.S. Capitol. The account, which had more than 57,000 tweets, was a significant tool for Trump's direct communication with the public.

"After close review of recent Tweets from the @realDonaldTrump account and the context around them we have permanently suspended the account due to the risk of further incitement of violence," Twitter Safety said in a statement.

The suspension came after a mob of Trump supporters stormed the Capitol building on January 6, 2021, in an attempt to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. Five people died as a result of the violence.

Peter Costanzo, an online marketing director who helped Trump join Twitter in 2009, suggested the @realDonaldTrump handle. "He was very excited about it," Costanzo told The Associated Press. "He loved the idea of being able to communicate directly with his supporters."

Trump used the platform extensively during his presidency, often bypassing official media channels. His messages ranged from promotional posts to attacks on political opponents and controversial statements. In his final months on the platform, Twitter flagged 471 of Trump's tweets for misinformation.

Sam Nunberg, a former Trump adviser, said Trump's Twitter account was a critical part of his political strategy. "He used it to go around the mainstream media and speak directly to his supporters," Nunberg said. "It was a game changer."

Trump's account was used to announce major decisions and insults alike. In 2017, he used Twitter to announce the United States' withdrawal from the Paris climate accord. In 2019, he used the platform to attack Democratic congresswomen, calling them the "Squad" and telling them to "go back" to their countries of origin.

Former President Trump's eldest son, Donald Trump Jr., criticized Twitter for banning his father's account while allowing leaders of authoritarian regimes to remain on the platform. "They're allowing dictators and authoritarians to use their platform to spread propaganda and lies, but they ban American citizens," Trump Jr. told Fox News.

Historians may look back on @realDonaldTrump's tweets as a window into Trump's thoughts and presidency. "These tweets provide a unique insight into the mind of a president and the way he communicated with the American people," said Julian Zelizer, a professor of history and public affairs at Princeton University. "They will be an important part of the historical record."

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin declined to testify in his own defense during the trial over the death of George Floyd, instead invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination on Friday.

With closing arguments set to begin Monday and jury deliberation to follow, the outcome of the closely watched trial is highly anticipated, prompting Minneapolis public schools to shift to distance learning in anticipation of a verdict. The city is on edge, with ongoing protests over another police shooting in the Minneapolis suburb of Brooklyn Center.

Chauvin, 45, is charged with second-degree murder, third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in Floyd's May 25, 2020, death. He faces up to 40 years in prison for the most serious charge. The defense rested its case after two days of testimony, in contrast to the prosecution's two weeks.

Worldwide protests were triggered by bystander video showing Chauvin pressing his knee against Floyd's neck for 9 minutes, 29 seconds, as Floyd repeatedly said he couldn't breathe. Prosecutors argue Floyd died due to Chauvin's knee pressed against his neck or close to it for 9 1/2 minutes. The medical examiner testified that Floyd's heart stopped while Chauvin had his knee on Floyd's neck.

The defense, meanwhile, aimed to present Chauvin's actions as reasonable and suggested Floyd's death was due to health issues and drug use. The only time Chauvin has been heard defending himself was through body-camera footage shown to the jury.

The jury of six women and six men, including two alternates, has heard testimony from more than 40 witnesses, including police officers, medical experts and bystanders. They have seen numerous videos, including bystander footage of Floyd's arrest and body-camera footage from the officers involved.

Prosecutors called several use-of-force experts who testified that Chauvin's use of force against Floyd was excessive and violated department policy. Defense witnesses testified that Chauvin followed his training and that Floyd's death was not caused by the officer's actions.

One of the prosecution's key witnesses was Dr. Martin Tobin, a pulmonologist who testified that the way Floyd was pinned to the pavement prevented him from getting enough oxygen. Floyd's autopsy report listed heart disease and fentanyl and methamphetamine use as contributing factors in his death, but Tobin said Floyd would not have died if not for Chauvin's actions.

The defense called several medical experts who testified that Floyd's use of drugs and underlying health conditions were the cause of his death. The defense also called police use-of-force experts who testified that Chauvin's actions were reasonable.

One of the defense's key witnesses was Barry Brodd, a use-of-force expert who testified that Chauvin's actions were reasonable and that Floyd died due to his underlying health conditions and drug use. Brodd also testified that Floyd's behavior leading up to his arrest, including his refusal to comply with officers and his struggle to get back into his car, contributed to his death.

The jury also watched body-camera footage of Floyd's arrest and Chauvin's interview with investigators after Floyd's death. In the footage, Chauvin can be heard telling another officer that he thought Floyd was a "big dude" and that Floyd "kept fighting" even after he was on the ground.

Chauvin's decision not to testify was a surprise to some legal experts, who had expected him to take the stand and explain his actions. But others said it was a wise move given the strength of the prosecution's case and the potential for damaging testimony.

The trial is happening amid ongoing protests over another police shooting in the Minneapolis suburb of Brooklyn Center. Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man, was shot and killed by a white officer during a traffic stop on April 11. The officer, Kim Potter, has since resigned and been charged with second-degree manslaughter.

The trial's outcome is expected to have significant implications for race relations in the United States and the debate over police use of force. Regardless of the verdict, it is likely to spark further protests and unrest.

In the meantime, the city of Minneapolis is on edge, with National Guard troops and other law enforcement agencies on standby to maintain order. Schools have shifted to distance learning, and many businesses have boarded up their windows in anticipation of unrest.

The trial is expected to conclude with closing arguments on Monday, after which the jury will begin deliberations. It is unclear how long it will take for the jury to reach a verdict.

Regardless of the outcome, the trial of Derek Chauvin is sure to be a defining moment in American history, one that will be remembered for generations to come.

Kathy Hochul Sworn In as New York's First Female Governor: Navigating Ethics, COVID-19, and Political Challenges

New York's 57th governor, Kathy Hochul, was sworn in on August 24, 2021, becoming the first woman to hold the office in the state's history. Replacing Andrew Cuomo, who resigned amid sexual harassment allegations and criticism over his handling of COVID-19 in nursing homes, Hochul pledged to bring ethics and transparency back to Albany.

Hochul, a former lieutenant governor since 2015, distanced herself from Cuomo's administration, vowing to remove any aides implicated in unethical practices as reported by the state attorney general. "I'm going to be a governor for all New Yorkers, not just for those who are in the inner circle," she declared during her inaugural address.

The new governor faces numerous challenges, including managing the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, distributing rental assistance, and potentially extending an eviction moratorium. Hochul highlighted her commitment to ethics and promised to support legislation for worker protections and oversight.

Professor Emeritus of Political Science at Hunter College, Kenneth Sherrill, commented on the significance of Hochul's election: "Governor Hochul is stepping into a tumultuous situation. New Yorkers are eager for a fresh start and a return to a more ethical and effective government."

Andrew Cuomo's tenure was marred by sexual harassment allegations from several women, which led to his resignation. In response to the allegations, Erica Vladimer, Co-founder of the Sexual Harassment Working Group, stated, "Governor Hochul's election represents a turning point for New York. We are hopeful that she will usher in a new era of accountability and transparency."

However, questions have arisen over potential conflicts of interest involving Hochul's husband, William Hochul Jr., who works for Delaware North. John Kaehny, Executive Director of Reinvent Albany, emphasized the importance of transparency: "Governor Hochul must take immediate action to address any potential conflicts of interest. New Yorkers demand transparency and accountability from their elected officials."

Hochul addressed these concerns during a press conference, stating, "My husband's employment will not influence my decisions as governor. I will ensure that all conflicts are disclosed and handled appropriately."

Hochul's political background includes being a moderate Democrat with roots in conservative Western New York. Her tenure faces scrutiny from both progressives and potential gubernatorial candidates as the next election approaches.

Progressive activist groups have criticized Hochul for her close ties to the Cuomo administration and her past support for certain policies, such as hydraulic fracturing (fracking) and charter schools. Meanwhile, potential gubernatorial candidates, including Attorney General Letitia James and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, have announced their intentions to run in the 2022 Democratic primary.

Despite these challenges, Hochul remains committed to her vision for New York. "I will work tirelessly to unite our state and move forward," she stated during her inaugural address. "Together, we will rebuild a stronger, fairer, and more just New York for all."

Screech is Gone: Dustin Diamond, Beloved 'Saved by the Bell' Star, Dies at 44 After Brief Battle with Lung Cancer

Dustin Diamond, best known for his role as the lovable yet awkward Screech Powell on the iconic '90s sitcom "Saved by the Bell," passed away on February 1, 2021, at the young age of 44. The actor, who was diagnosed with Stage 4 small cell carcinoma just a month prior, succumbed to the disease despite undergoing chemotherapy.

In an interview on "Dr. Oz" in 2019, Diamond spoke candidly about his health struggles. "I've had this pain in my side for quite some time now, and it's been getting progressively worse," he said. "I've had some tests done, and they've come back negative for cancer, but I'm not convinced. I think there's something more to it." Sadly, his suspicions were confirmed only a few weeks later.

Diamond joined the cast of "Saved by the Bell" in 1989 and remained a series regular until its conclusion in 1993. He also appeared in several spinoffs, including "Saved by the Bell: The College Years" and "Saved by the Bell: The New Class."

Relations between Diamond and his castmates soured in 2009 when he released a tell-all book, "Behind the Bell," which contained unflattering anecdotes about his colleagues. However, he later made amends with some members of the cast, including Mario Lopez and Tiffani Thiessen.

In a heartfelt Instagram post, Lopez paid tribute to his late co-star, writing, "Deeply saddened to hear of the passing of Dustin Diamond, a true colleague who I grew up with and worked with on 'Saved By The Bell.' My heart goes out to his family and loved ones."

Thiessen also took to Instagram to express her condolences, stating, "I am deeply saddened to hear the news of Dustin Diamond's passing. My sincere condolences to his family for their loss. The passing of Dustin is a painful reminder of the fragility of life. My thoughts are with his loved ones during this difficult time."

Diamond's post-"Saved by the Bell" career consisted of minor roles in movies and appearances on reality and quiz shows. In 2006, he made headlines for a sex tape that was released, which he later revealed was a hoax using a stuntman and his face added digitally.

Reflecting on his experiences as a child star in a 2019 interview, Diamond lamented the loss of a normal childhood. "I didn't get to experience a lot of things that kids my age did," he said. "I was always working, and I didn't have the opportunity to just be a kid and hang out with my friends and do normal things."

Despite his struggles, Diamond remained optimistic and hopeful, stating, "I'm still here, and I'm still fighting. I'm not giving up. I'm going to keep pushing forward and see what I can do to turn things around."

Tragically, Diamond's battle with cancer came to an end before he could fully realize his dreams. He was not part of the "Saved by the Bell" revival on Peacock in 2020, which featured many of his former castmates.

The news of Diamond's passing serves as a sobering reminder of the fragility of life and the importance of cherishing every moment. His legacy as Screech Powell will continue to live on in the hearts and minds of fans who grew up with him on "Saved by the Bell."

Diamond once said in an interview, "I've always believed in second chances, and I think everyone deserves a second chance." Unfortunately, his own second chance was cut short. Rest in peace, Dustin Diamond.

Fact Check: Biden Did Not Cause East Coast Fuel Crisis, Despite Conservative Claims

President Joe Biden's first major crisis has been misleadingly labeled as "Biden's Gas Crisis" by conservatives and social media posts, despite the actual cause being a cyberattack on the Colonial Pipeline that supplies nearly half of the East Coast's fuel.

"This is not a Biden gas crisis. This is a crisis caused by a criminal act," President Biden said during a press conference on the situation. The attack, which occurred on May 7, led to the pipeline's shutdown and subsequent fuel shortages in several East Coast states.

Despite Biden's clarification, some conservative figures continued to spread misinformation. Former Florida congressional candidate Chuck Callesto tweeted, "Joe Biden's policies have created the perfect storm for a gas crisis. And now, a cyberattack has exacerbated the situation."

U.S. Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) echoed similar sentiments on Fox News, stating, "President Biden is the cause of this crisis with his war on American energy." The Colonial Pipeline attack and subsequent fuel shortages had nothing to do with Biden's policies or executive orders.

Fox Nation host Tomi Lahren tweeted, "Let's not forget, this is a man who canceled the Keystone XL pipeline project, the very thing that could help alleviate some of the pain at the pump." However, the Keystone XL pipeline would not have had any impact on the current gas shortage.

Former President Donald Trump also weighed in on the situation, tweeting, "Joe Biden's incompetence has led to the worst energy crisis in American history." Sean Hannity, a Fox News Channel host, also accused Biden of causing the crisis during a segment on his show.

The Biden administration is already facing multiple challenges, including a disappointing jobs report, inflation signs, violence in Israel, and efforts to manage COVID-19. The gas pipeline shutdown exacerbates public relations challenges for Biden, amidst rising gas prices as COVID-19 restrictions are loosened.

Republican strategist Doug Heye mentioned that the situation provided an opportunity for conservatives to push their message, amidst other Republican divisions. "This is an opportunity for Republicans to show they can provide solutions to problems," Heye said.

The narrative of Biden being responsible for the gas crisis gained momentum through social media and conservative commentary, with some going as far as comparing the situation to socialist regimes and the 1979 fuel shortage under President Carter.

Biden administration officials, including Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg, have urged against panic buying, stating that the situation is temporary and that the pipeline is expected to be back online by the end of the week.

The Colonial Pipeline attack is being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA). The pipeline, which transports gasoline, diesel fuel, and jet fuel, was hit by a ransomware attack that encrypted its data and demanded a ransom payment.

The fuel shortage caused by the pipeline shutdown has led to long lines at gas stations and price increases in some areas. According to AAA, the national average price for a gallon of gas was $3.01 as of May 11, up from $2.88 a week earlier.

The Biden administration has taken steps to mitigate the impact of the fuel shortage, including waiving the Jones Act, which requires that all goods transported between U.S. ports be carried on American-flagged vessels. This waiver allows foreign-flagged vessels to transport fuel between U.S. ports to help alleviate the shortage.

Tiger Woods' Confusion in Hospital Interview, Low Blood Pressure, and Unanswered Questions Surround February Car Crash

In the immediate aftermath of the February car crash that left golf legend Tiger Woods with multiple injuries, the athlete expressed confusion about his location during a hospital interview. "I thought I was in Florida," Woods told medical staff, according to Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva.

The revelation came as part of a recent data report on the crash, compiled by Sergeant Michael Downing of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. The report also disclosed that Woods' blood pressure was too low to administer pain medication following the accident.

Jonathan Cherney, a former police detective and forensic crash reconstruction expert, commented on the significance of Woods' condition: "It's not uncommon for patients to be disoriented or confused following a traumatic incident, especially when they've sustained injuries. Low blood pressure can exacerbate these symptoms."

The report also revealed the discovery of an empty pharmaceutical bottle at the crash scene. However, investigators found no reason to believe Woods was impaired by alcohol or drugs at the time of the crash. Officer Justin Smith, who interviewed Woods post-crash, reported that the golfer was "somewhat combative" due to the trauma and shock from his injuries.

According to the data report, Woods was traveling over 82 mph in a 45-mph zone when the crash occurred. Vehicle data indicates he applied the gas pedal at 99% just before the crash. There was no evidence of braking or steering to avoid the crash, leading to speculation that Woods might have been unconscious.

Sergeant Downing explained, "The lack of braking or steering input prior to the crash is a concern, but it's important to remember that the availability of this data doesn't definitively prove that Woods was unconscious. It's just one piece of the puzzle."

Deputy Kyle Sullivan, who arrived at the scene shortly after the crash, noted that Woods appeared to be "incoherent and confused" when he spoke to him. "His speech was slurred, and he seemed disoriented," Sullivan recalled.

This is not the first time Woods has been involved in a driving incident. In 2009, he received a careless driving citation after crashing into a fire hydrant and a tree outside his Florida home. Five years later, he was arrested for driving under the influence of prescription drugs.

Sheriff Villanueva emphasized the importance of the ongoing investigation, stating, "Our goal is to provide a clear and accurate account of the events leading up to this tragic incident. We will continue to examine all available evidence and interview witnesses to ensure a comprehensive understanding of what occurred."

Biden Announces Sweeping Vaccine Mandates Affecting Up to 100 Million Americans

WASHINGTON (AP) – President Joe Biden on Thursday announced sweeping new vaccine mandates affecting up to 100 million Americans in an effort to combat the spread of the COVID-19 delta variant. The mandates apply to private-sector employees, health care workers, federal contractors, and others.

"We've been patient, but our patience is wearing thin. And your refusal has cost all of us," Biden said during a speech at the White House, criticizing unvaccinated Americans. "So, please, do the right thing – get vaccinated."

Republican leaders and some union chiefs quickly accused Biden of overstepping his authority and violating constitutional rights. Gov. Henry McMaster of South Carolina was among the critics.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer convicted of murder and manslaughter in the death of George Floyd, has hired attorney William Mohrman to represent him in his appeal, according to a court filing.

Mohrman, a partner at Mohrman, Kaminkow & Manning, P.A., filed a notice of appearance with the Minnesota Court of Appeals on Monday, indicating his representation of Chauvin.

Chauvin, 45, was convicted of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter and sentenced to 22 1/2 years in prison. He is currently incarcerated at the Minnesota Correctional Facility-Oak Park Heights.

In the filing, Chauvin listed 14 grounds for appeal, including his claim of an unfair trial location and the lack of jury sequestration, among other issues.

The request for a public defender to represent Chauvin on appeal was denied due to an assessment of his assets, according to a spokesperson for the Minnesota Public Defender's Office. Chauvin's legal representation was originally funded by the Minnesota Police and Peace Officers Association's legal defense fund.

Mohrman's firm has been involved in controversial lawsuits, including an attempt to vacate the 2020 presidential election results in Pennsylvania. The firm also represents Minnesota health care workers suing over COVID-19 vaccine mandates. A federal judge recently denied a temporary restraining order related to the vaccine mandate lawsuit.

Chauvin also faces federal charges for violating Floyd's civil rights, to which he has pleaded not guilty.

In a statement, Mohrman said, "We will thoroughly review the record in this case and assess all available legal arguments for appeal. Our focus will be on ensuring that Mr. Chauvin receives a fair and impartial appeal process."

Mohrman's firm did not respond to requests for comment on the nature of their involvement in the presidential election lawsuit or the vaccine mandate lawsuit.

Chauvin's trial, which took place in Hennepin County, was moved from the courthouse in Minneapolis due to security concerns and logistical challenges. Some defense attorneys and legal experts argued that the location change could have prejudiced the jury pool and violated Chauvin's right to a fair trial.

Jury sequestration, or the isolation of jurors during a trial, was also a topic of debate during Chauvin's trial. Some legal experts argued that sequestration would have helped prevent outside influence on the jury and ensured a fair trial.

Chauvin's appeal is expected to take several months to a year to be resolved. In the meantime, Floyd's family and their legal team are pursuing a civil lawsuit against Chauvin and the city of Minneapolis.

Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man, died on May 25, 2020, after Chauvin pressed his knee into Floyd's neck for more than nine minutes during an arrest. Floyd's death sparked widespread protests against police brutality and racial injustice around the world.

The charges against Chauvin differed in their interpretation of Chauvin's intent. The second-degree unintentional murder charge required proof that Chauvin did not intend to kill Floyd but instead caused his death during the commission of a felony. The third-degree murder charge required proof that Chauvin showed a depraved disregard for human life. The second-degree manslaughter charge involved Chauvin's culpable negligence creating an unreasonable risk of death or great bodily harm.

Fact Check: Biden's Inauguration – Limited Crowds, Security Threats, and Misinformation

Biden's inauguration maintained strict coronavirus precautions, continuing practices from his presidential campaign. These measures included virtual events, limited attendance, and mask-wearing.

The absence of large crowds marked a significant change from traditional inauguration ceremonies, which typically attract hundreds of thousands of spectators.

Another false claim that circulated was that the National Mall was intentionally flooded to make the inauguration look less impressive. However, this was debunked as there was no evidence to support the claim.

Additionally, there were allegations that Biden's inauguration was not a legitimate transfer of power and that the election results were fraudulent. These claims have been extensively debunked by numerous fact-checking organizations and courts.

A common myth was that Biden only received 8,000 votes in the 2020 election. In reality, he received over 81 million votes, making it the most votes ever received by a presidential candidate in U.S. history.

Misinformation about the National Guard's role during the inauguration also emerged, with some claiming that they were being used for crowd control or even detaining Americans. However, the National Guard was there solely for security purposes.

A false claim that went viral was that the National Mall was being used as a detention camp for protestors. This was debunked, as there was no evidence to support the claim and the National Mall remained open to the public throughout the inauguration weekend.

There were also allegations that Biden was not a legitimate president due to his age or citizenship status. These claims have been extensively debunked, as Biden is a natural-born U.S. citizen and met the age requirement to serve as president.

Another false claim was that Biden's inauguration was funded by foreign governments. However, all inauguration funds came from private donations and the federal government.

Misinformation surrounding the COVID-19 vaccines and their distribution during the inauguration also emerged. There were claims that the vaccines were not effective or that they were being used for population control. These claims have been debunked by numerous scientific studies and health organizations.

As the new administration begins, it is crucial to remain vigilant against misinformation and to fact-check claims before sharing them. The ongoing pandemic and heightened security concerns have made it more important than ever to separate fact from fiction.

In conclusion, the 2021 presidential inauguration faced unique challenges due to the coronavirus pandemic and security concerns. Misinformation surrounding the event was rampant, with false claims about crowd sizes, flags, election results, and various other aspects. By fact-checking these claims and separating fact from fiction, we can ensure a more informed public discourse.

Capitol Chaos: How Missed Warnings, Insufficient Preparation, and Leadership Failures Led to the January 6 Insurrection

The violence that unfolded on January 6 resulted in 73 Capitol Police and 65 DC Metropolitan Police officers being injured. One US Capitol Police officer, Brian Sicknick, tragically lost his life due to injuries sustained during the riot.

Communication failures during the riot left officers feeling abandoned and uncertain about their roles and responsibilities. Some officers reported not receiving clear instructions from their superiors, leading to confusion and disorganization.

Bureaucracy also delayed the National Guard response, which did not arrive until hours after the riot began. The slow response time exacerbated the chaos and made it more difficult for law enforcement to regain control of the situation.

The report highlighted the need for better communication, equipment, and planning to ensure the safety of lawmakers and the general public.

Leading up to the riot, online forums and social media platforms were rife with discussions about coordinated efforts to disrupt the certification of the 2020 presidential election results. These threats were not taken seriously enough by law enforcement, and valuable time was lost in the days leading up to the event.

The US Capitol Police were warned about the potential for violence on January 6, with specific information about the possibility of armed protests. However, these warnings were not acted upon effectively due to poor information sharing and a lack of urgency.

The rioters were able to breach the Capitol's perimeter due to a lack of manpower and inadequate barricades. Once inside the building, they were able to wreak havoc, damaging property and engaging in violent confrontations with law enforcement officers.

The US Capitol Police were outnumbered and outmatched by the rioters, who were armed with various weapons, including batons, bear spray, and flags. The officers were forced to retreat in some areas, allowing the rioters to take control of parts of the Capitol complex.

The chaos that ensued on January 6 was a result of a perfect storm of missed warnings, insufficient preparation, and leadership failures. Had law enforcement agencies taken the threats more seriously and taken appropriate measures to secure the Capitol, the riot could have been prevented or at least mitigated.

In the aftermath of the riot, there were calls for accountability and reform within the US Capitol Police department. Critics pointed to a culture of complacency and a lack of resources as contributing factors to the department's poor response.

The events of January 6 exposed significant vulnerabilities in the security of the US Capitol and the broader American democratic process. The insurrection served as a wake-up call for lawmakers and law enforcement agencies to take the threat of domestic terrorism more seriously.

In response to the riot, the US Capitol Police underwent a major overhaul, with a renewed focus on preparing for potential threats and improving communication and coordination between law enforcement agencies.

The January 6 insurrection was a dark day in American history, one that exposed the fragility of the democratic process and the importance of effective law enforcement and security measures.

Despite the progress made since the riot, there is still work to be done to ensure the safety and security of the US Capitol and the American people. The events of January 6 serve as a reminder of the importance of vigilance and preparedness in the face of potential threats.

Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 Vaccines: Two Doses for Maximum Protection vs. Johnson & Johnson's Single-Dose Advantage

The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines have been instrumental in the global fight against the coronavirus pandemic. While both these vaccines require two doses for full efficacy, the Johnson & Johnson (J&J) vaccine stands out with its single-dose advantage. Understanding the differences between these vaccines, their efficacy, and dosing schedules is crucial in navigating the ongoing vaccine rollout.

The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines use messenger RNA (mRNA) technology to trigger an immune response against the SARS-CoV-2 virus. mRNA acts like a set of instructions that instructs the body's cells to produce a specific protein, in this case, a piece of the coronavirus. The immune system then recognizes these proteins as foreign invaders and produces an immune response. Initial immunity is observed after the first dose of both Pfizer-BioNTech (52-91% effective) and Moderna (50.8-92.1% effective) vaccines. However, full immunity from these vaccines typically takes around 2 weeks after the second dose. The second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is administered 3 weeks after the first, while Moderna's second dose comes 4 weeks after the first. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) allows the second dose to be administered up to 4 days earlier than recommended or up to 6 weeks (42 days) after the first dose in certain situations.

The discussions about delaying or eliminating the second dose to increase vaccine coverage have raised concerns about long-term immunity and variant emergence. The CDC does not recommend mixing Pfizer and Moderna vaccines; the same product should be used for both doses to ensure optimal immune response. Vaccine effectiveness is 95% for Pfizer-BioNTech and 94.1% for Moderna after the second dose. These high efficacy rates make it essential to prioritize the timely administration of the full recommended dosing schedule to protect as many people as possible against the virus and its potential variants.

U.S. Deputy National Security Advisor Anne Neuberger acknowledged the severity of the situation, stating, "We're working closely with industry partners to prevent ransomware from moving from IT to operational technology (OT) systems, as we've seen in the Colonial Pipeline incident."

Industry experts advocate for better visibility and defense-in-depth strategies to respond more precisely to cyberattacks. Leo Simonovich, Vice President and Global Head of Industrial Cyber and Digital Security at Siemens Energy AG, emphasized, "Companies need to understand their assets, implement multiple protection layers, and adopt a defense-in-depth strategy to effectively respond to cyberattacks."

Questions arise about Colonial's visibility into its systems and whether it could have taken a more targeted approach to the shutdown. Barbara Rembiesa, President and CEO of the International Association of IT Asset Managers, explained, "Having a comprehensive inventory of IT and OT assets is crucial for effective threat detection and response. Best practices in cybersecurity involve multiple protection layers and network segmentation but are not foolproof. Johan Vermij, Research Analyst specializing in the internet of things at 451 Research, noted, "While it's important for companies to implement best practices in cybersecurity, no solution is foolproof. The incident sparked discussion on the need for more flexible policies and additional pipeline infrastructure for redundancy. Friedman commented, "Given the increasing risk of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure, it's essential for policymakers and industry stakeholders to consider implementing more flexible policies and investing in additional pipeline infrastructure for redundancy."

Securing OT systems poses challenges due to their initial design and maintenance requirements. Simonovich explained, "OT systems were designed with operational reliability in mind, not cybersecurity. This makes securing them a complex challenge that requires a deep understanding of both the technical and operational aspects of these systems."

A comprehensive approach to OT security, including detailed asset inventories and business impact analysis, is essential for resilience. Rembiesa emphasized, "To effectively secure OT systems, companies need to conduct thorough asset inventories, understand the business impact of a potential cyberattack, and implement robust security measures tailored to the unique requirements of these systems."

Concluding Remarks: The Colonial Pipeline cyberattack serves as a wake-up call for industries and governments to prioritize cybersecurity and infrastructure resilience. As the interconnectedness of IT and OT systems continues to grow, so too will the risks and potential consequences of cyberattacks. By implementing best practices, investing in redundancy, and adopting a comprehensive approach to securing both IT and OT systems, organizations can better protect themselves against the growing threat of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Juror Brandon Mitchell Describes Relaxed Deliberations, Emotional Toll in Derek Chauvin Trial

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Brandon Mitchell, the first juror to speak publicly about the Derek Chauvin trial, described the deliberations as relaxed and methodical, leading to a unanimous conviction in the death of George Floyd.

"The deliberations were methodical and professional," Mitchell said in an interview Wednesday. "We listened carefully to each other's perspectives and made our decision based on the facts presented in the trial."

Mitchell, a 31-year-old transportation supervisor, compared the emotional toll of the trial to attending a funeral every day. "It was an intense and emotional experience," he said. "But we were all focused on doing the right thing and making sure justice was served."

The jury convicted Chauvin of second- and third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter on April 20, 2021.

Mitchell highlighted the importance of video evidence and the testimony of Dr. Martin Tobin, a breathing expert, in reaching the verdict. "The video evidence was compelling, and Dr. Tobin's testimony really helped us understand what was happening to George Floyd during those final moments," he said.

Jurors took a preliminary vote on manslaughter first, then moved on to third-degree murder, and finally agreed on second-degree murder. "It was a process of elimination," Mitchell explained. "We started with the least serious charge and worked our way up to the most serious one."

Mitchell thought the defense's strategy of portraying bystanders as a threat was ineffective since they didn't appear hostile. "The defense tried to make it seem like the bystanders were a threat, but we could all see that they were just concerned citizens trying to help," he said.

Chauvin's choice not to testify did not impact the trial's outcome, according to Mitchell. "His decision not to testify didn't really factor into our deliberations," he said. "We based our decision on the evidence presented in the trial, not on what Derek Chauvin had to say."

Mitchell felt no pressure to reach a verdict to prevent potential violent protests. "There was no pressure from outside sources to rush to a decision," he said. "We took our time and made sure we were making the right decision based on the facts presented in the trial."

Mitchell was careful to hide his involvement in the trial from his basketball team and conversed little about the case with his family. "I didn't want anyone to know I was on the jury until after the trial was over," he said. "I didn't want any outside influences to affect my decision-making."

Mitchell refrained from predicting the outcome for the other three officers charged in Floyd's death, suggesting their trials might present different challenges. "Each case is unique, and I can't speak to what will happen in the other officers' trials," he said. "We focused on the evidence presented in Derek Chauvin's trial and made our decision based on that."

Rittenhouse Acquitted in Kenosha Shootings, Sparking Debate on Guns, Vigilantism, and Race

KENOSHA, Wis. (AP) – A jury on Friday, Nov. 19, 2021, acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse of all charges in the 2020 Kenosha shootings that left two men dead and a third wounded during protests over the police shooting of Jacob Blake. The verdict has sparked a heated national debate over guns, vigilantism, and racial injustice in the United States.

Defense attorney Mark Richards argued that Rittenhouse, then 17, acted in self-defense during the tumultuous protests in this Rust Belt city. "My client was put in a position where he had to make a decision as to his survival," Richards said in his closing statement. "He made that decision based on his training, based on the threats that were made to him, based on the conduct of other people that night."

The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a prominent civil rights leader, criticized the verdict. "This acquittal sends a dangerous message to would-be vigilantes," Jackson stated, "that you can go out and shoot unarmed protestors in the name of self-defense, and you will be exonerated."

President Joe Biden, in a statement, expressed concern about the verdict's potential impact on the nation. "While the verdict in Kenosha will leave many Americans feeling angry and concerned, myself included, we must acknowledge that the jury has spoken," Biden said. "I urge everyone to express their views peacefully, consistent with the rule of law."

Former President Donald Trump weighed in, tweeting, "Congratulations to Kyle Rittenhouse on his complete exoneration. It's a shame his life has been totally destroyed, a sad commentary on our justice system."

Kenosha County District Attorney Michael Graveley argued that Rittenhouse was a "wannabe soldier" who "was looking for trouble that night." Prosecutor Thomas Binger accused Rittenhouse of illegally carrying a rifle and inciting the confrontations that led to the shootings.

Rittenhouse was charged with homicide, attempted homicide, and reckless endangering for killing Joseph Rosenbaum and Anthony Huber and wounding Gaige Grosskreutz. During the trial, Grosskreutz testified that Rittenhouse shot him in self-defense after he pointed a gun at the teen.

Wisconsin Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes called the verdict "a slap in the face to the Black community." Mark McCloskey, a Republican candidate for U.S. Senate in Missouri, defended Rittenhouse's actions, stating, "He was exercising his Second Amendment rights, and he's a patriot."

Corey Chirafisi, another Rittenhouse defense attorney, emphasized the importance of Wisconsin's self-defense laws in the case. "The law is clear," Chirafisi stated during closing arguments. "You don't have to retreat. You have the right to stand your ground."

The Rittenhouse trial and verdict come amid other high-profile trials reflecting racial divisions in the U.S., such as the trial of Derek Chauvin for the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Protesters took to the streets in Kenosha and other cities following the Rittenhouse verdict.

Novavax COVID-19 Vaccine Shines in Phase 3 Trials with 90.4% Efficacy and 100% Protection against Severe Disease

In a significant breakthrough in the fight against COVID-19, the Novavax vaccine (NVX-CoV2373) has demonstrated impressive results in a Phase 3 clinical trial. The trial, known as PREVENT-19, was funded by the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) and enrolled 29,960 volunteers in the U.S. and Mexico. The study showed that the vaccine had an efficacy rate of 90.4% in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 infections.

The trial results were even more promising when it came to protection against moderate and severe disease. NVX-CoV2373 showed 100% efficacy in preventing these more severe cases of COVID-19. This is particularly significant as severe disease can lead to hospitalization and even death.

The vaccine also proved effective in high-risk individuals, including those aged 65 or older and those under 65 with certain comorbidities. NVX-CoV2373 showed an efficacy rate of 91.0% in this population. These findings are particularly important as older adults and those with underlying health conditions are at greater risk for severe disease and complications from COVID-19.

The most common side effects reported in the trial were mild-to-moderate injection site pain, fatigue, headache, and muscle pain, which lasted less than two days. These side effects are similar to those reported with other COVID-19 vaccines and are generally considered to be mild and short-lived.

The PREVENT-19 trial used a 2:1 ratio for vaccine to placebo distribution and maintained a study blind to ensure that participants and investigators did not know who received the vaccine. The study results were based on 77 symptomatic COVID-19 cases observed, with 63 in the placebo group and 14 in the vaccine group.

NVX-CoV2373 uses recombinant protein nanoparticle technology and includes an adjuvant to enhance the immune response. This technology is different from the messenger RNA (mRNA) technology used in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. In May 2021, the PREVENT-19 trial expanded to include adolescents aged 12-17. The COVID-19 Prevention Network (CoVPN) and various health organizations are involved in facilitating and overseeing the trial. With these promising results, NVX-CoV2373 is poised to become another valuable tool in the global fight against COVID-19.

Scammers Thrive on Facebook and Google: Report Finds 34% of Google-Reported Scam Ads Not Removed, Victims Urge Tougher Action from Tech Giants

Facebook and Google, two tech giants that dominate the digital advertising landscape, have come under fire for their inability to effectively combat scam ads on their platforms, even after they are reported by users. With the global population spending more time indoors due to lockdowns, online fraud has seen a significant increase, leaving consumers vulnerable to financial losses and identity theft.

According to a study by British consumer group Which?, 34% of Google-reported scam ads were not removed, and 26% for Facebook-reported ads. This startling revelation has sparked accusations of a lax approach from Facebook, which prides itself on its community standards and commitment to user safety.

"Facebook has a responsibility to protect its users from scams and misleading ads," says Adam French, Consumer Rights Expert at Which?. "It's concerning that so many ads reported as potentially fraudulent are not being taken down, leaving people at risk of financial loss or identity theft."

Scammers are taking advantage of the situation by creating fake ads using established brands' logos and branding to lure unsuspecting victims into parting with their financial details. Consumers are more likely to come across fraudulent ads on Facebook than on Google, with the study revealing that 58% of all scam ads were found on Facebook.

Google spokesperson, when reached for comment, stated, "We have strict policies against misleading and harmful content, and we remove ads that violate these policies. However, no system is perfect, and we're constantly working to improve and evolve our approach."

Facebook, too, defended its stance, with a spokesperson asserting, "We take the issue of scam ads seriously and invest heavily in systems and technology to detect and remove them. We remove millions of ads each week that violate our policies, and we continue to improve our systems to stay ahead of scammers."

The issue of online scams has gained significant attention in the UK, with consumers urging the government to take tougher action. The proposed Online Safety Bill in the UK could impose fines on tech companies failing to remove 'harmful' content, providing a potential solution to the problem.

"The Online Safety Bill is a step in the right direction," says French. "It's crucial that tech companies are held accountable for the content they allow on their platforms, especially when it comes to scams and misleading ads."

Insider previously reported on scammers using fake quotes from celebrities to promote fraudulent cryptocurrency schemes on YouTube. The pervasive nature of online scams underscores the need for increased vigilance and action from both consumers and tech companies.

As the digital landscape continues to evolve, so too must the strategies of scammers. Consumers must remain cautious and informed, while tech companies must invest in more robust systems to combat fraudulent activity. The stakes are high, and the consequences of inaction can be severe.

Norsk Hydro's Unyielding Response to a $70 Million Ransomware Attack: "We Would Not Pay"

Norsk Hydro, the Norwegian renewable energy and aluminum manufacturing giant, faced an unprecedented challenge when it became the latest victim of a ransomware attack on March 18, 2019. The assault crippled the company's network, locking out users from over 3,000 servers and thousands of PCs, encrypting key areas of the IT infrastructure. The attack came on the same day that Hilde Merete Aasheim took the helm as Norsk Hydro's new CEO.

CEO Aasheim recounted her first day on the job, stating, "We were in the middle of a normal working day when suddenly, we were hit by a cyberattack. I was just getting to know the organization, and this was definitely not what I had anticipated."

Norsk Hydro's Chief Information Officer (CIO), Jo De Vliegher, echoed Aasheim's sentiments, adding, "We were faced with a difficult decision: pay the ransom demanded by the hackers or not. We chose not to pay."

The decision not to pay the ransom came with significant operational disruptions. Norsk Hydro's IT network was left in shambles, forcing the company to revert to manual processes. Production was maintained through pen and paper for about three weeks. "It was a painful process," De Vliegher admitted. "But we knew that giving in to the hackers' demands would set a dangerous precedent."

The ransomware attack is estimated to have caused Norsk Hydro an estimated loss of $70 million. Despite the financial strain, the company opted to work with cybersecurity experts and the Norwegian National Cyber Security Centre to recover from the attack.

Microsoft also lent its support to Norsk Hydro during the recovery process. Microsoft President Brad Smith expressed solidarity with the company, stating, "We stand with Norsk Hydro during this difficult time. Cyberattacks like these are a threat to all organizations, regardless of size or industry."

The incident served as a major reevaluation of Norsk Hydro's cybersecurity measures and priorities. "We are taking a hard look at our cybersecurity defenses," Aasheim said. "This attack has shown us that we need to do more to protect our organization and our customers."

The U.S. Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) advised against paying ransoms in such situations. Eric Goldstein, Executive Assistant Director for Cybersecurity at CISA, stated, "Paying the ransom only fuels the criminal economy. It's a short-term solution with long-term consequences."

Goldstein's advice resonated with Aasheim and De Vliegher. "We knew that giving in to the hackers' demands would only encourage more attacks in the future," Aasheim concluded. "We stand firm in our decision not to pay the ransom, and we will continue to invest in our cybersecurity defenses to protect our organization and our customers."

As Norsk Hydro continues to recover from the attack, the company remains committed to its stance against ransomware payments. The incident serves as a reminder that the fight against cybercrime is an ongoing battle that requires a collective effort from organizations, governments, and cybersecurity experts.

Witnesses Recall Altercation Between Gabby Petito and Brian Laundrie at Jackson Hole Restaurant

JACKSON, Wyo. – In the days leading up to Gabby Petito's disappearance, an altercation between her and her fiancé, Brian Laundrie, was reportedly witnessed at a restaurant in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Witnesses Nina Celie Angelo and Matthew England, who were in town for a wedding, described the incident to FOX 13 News.

Angelo and England, both residents of Utah, were having dinner at the Merry Piglets Tex-Mex restaurant on August 27, 2021. According to Angelo, they saw Laundrie and Petito get into an argument with the staff over a bill or money.

"[Laundrie] was being really aggressive," Angelo said. "He was pounding on the counter. They wouldn't let him pay with a card, so he was insisting on paying with cash, and they didn't have change for a large bill."

Petito reportedly apologized for Laundrie's behavior during the incident. England, concerned by Laundrie's demeanor, decided to report the incident to the FBI.

"[Laundrie] was really agitated, and she seemed visibly upset," England explained. "So I just wanted to make sure everything was okay and that they were safe, and that was kind of the motivation behind calling it in."

The incident occurred just two days after Petito's final Instagram post and weeks after a domestic fight between the couple was reported in Moab, Utah. Bodycam footage from the Moab police response to that incident showed Petito in tears and Laundrie appearing calm. Petito later told police she was the one who instigated the altercation.

The couple's behavior at the restaurant and the Moab police bodycam footage were later used to identify them as the individuals seen arguing in the Merry Piglets video. Petito's disappearance followed soon after the restaurant incident, with her remains found later in a campsite north of Jackson Hole.

Brian Laundrie returned home to North Port, Florida, without Petito on September 1. He retained a lawyer and refused to speak with police about her disappearance. According to North Port police spokesperson Josh Taylor, Laundrie's behavior upon his return was inconsistent with that of someone who had just reported a loved one missing.

"[Laundrie's] demeanor was not consistent with someone who had just reported a missing person," Taylor said. "His response was not consistent with what we would have expected."

As the investigation into Petito's disappearance and Laundrie's involvement continues, the incident at the Merry Piglets restaurant remains a crucial piece of the puzzle. The witnesses' accounts provide valuable information about the couple's behavior in the days leading up to Petito's disappearance.

Angelo and England's decision to report the altercation to the FBI shows the importance of speaking up when witnessing potentially dangerous situations. Their actions may have helped bring attention to the case and potentially contributed to the eventual discovery of Petito's remains.

"I just wanted to make sure everything was okay, and that was kind of the motivation behind calling it in," England said. "It's a good reminder that if you see something, say something."

As the investigation into Petito's disappearance and Laundrie's involvement continues, FOX 13 News will continue to provide updates on the developing story.

Ever Given's Suez Canal Standstill: A Nautical Throwback to Ever Laurel's Plastic Toy Spill of '92

In the waters of the Suez Canal, a 200,000-tonne cargo ship, the Ever Given, has been lodged sideways since Tuesday, March 23, 2021. The colossal vessel, operated by Evergreen Marine Corporation on behalf of the ship's owner, Shoei Kisen, is blocking one of the world's busiest commercial sea routes.

This is not the first time Evergreen Marine Corporation or Shoei Kisen have found themselves in the headlines for a maritime mishap. In January 1992, a ship under their management - the Ever Laurel - spilled an estimated 28,800 plastic toys into the Pacific Ocean during a storm.

The Ever Laurel, owned by Technomar Shipping, arrived in the port of Tacoma, Washington state, a day late from Hong Kong after encountering heavy storms. The incident resulted in the release of approximately 7,200 each of plastic red beavers, blue turtles, green frogs, and classic yellow rubber ducks into the ocean.

Donovan Hohn's book 'Moby-Duck' chronicles the true story of the lost toys at sea and the ship's identity discovery through old shipping schedules. The captivating tale shed light on the unintended consequences of industrial shipping and the far-reaching impacts of seemingly insignificant objects.

Since then, oceanographers have utilized the floating toys, known as friendly floatees, to track currents and gain insights into the world's climate. The toys have traveled more than 27,360 kilometers and have washed up on many far shores, inspiring curiosity and wonder.

While the Ever Given currently blocks the Suez Canal, Evergreen Marine Corporation operates a different ship named the Ever Laurel. This Ever Laurel, built in 2012, travels between the Far East and South America.

Cargo ship spills are relatively common in stormy weather, with hundreds of containers lost from the One Apus in December 2020, north of Hawaii, as a recent example.

Marine accidents, particularly those involving container spills, pose significant risks to marine ecosystems and human populations. The release of hazardous materials can harm marine life and disrupt food chains. Additionally, plastics can take hundreds of years to decompose, leading to long-term environmental damage.

The Ever Laurel toy spill serves as a stark reminder of the potential consequences of maritime transportation. While efforts have been made to mitigate the risks, including stricter shipping regulations and improved container securing methods, accidents can still occur.

The Suez Canal incident, though not involving a cargo spill, highlights the importance of maintaining a functioning global shipping network. The canal is a crucial link between Europe and Asia, with approximately 10% of global trade passing through it annually.

The Ever Given's grounding in the Suez Canal underscores the significance of efficient and secure shipping practices. Efforts to refloat the vessel continue, with experts working around the clock to minimize the impact on global commerce.

As the world awaits the resolution of the Suez Canal standstill, the story of the Ever Laurel and its plastic toy spill serves as a reminder of the interconnectedness of our global economy and the potential consequences of mishaps at sea.

Efforts to clean up the plastic toys released during the Ever Laurel spill are ongoing. Organizations such as the Ocean Cleanup Project are working to remove marine debris from the world's oceans, reducing the risks to both marine life and human populations.

The tale of the Ever Laurel and its plastic toy spill is a testament to the resilience of nature and the ingenuity of humanity. As we continue to navigate the complexities of global commerce and maritime transportation, it serves as a reminder to remain vigilant and adaptable in the face of challenges.

Historic Building Tied to Louis Armstrong's Early Jazz Career Destroyed by Hurricane Ida

CNN – New Orleans, Louisiana – The historic building on South Rampart Street, near the French Quarter, that once housed the Karnofsky Tailor Shop and played a significant role in the early life of jazz legend Louis Armstrong was destroyed by Hurricane Ida.

The building, which dates back to the late 1800s, was a symbol of jazz history and a reminder of the influential relationship between Armstrong and the Karnofsky family.

John Baron, a musicologist and author of "Louis Armstrong: Master of Modernism," shared his disappointment over the loss.

"The Karnofsky Tailor Shop was an important part of Armstrong's formative years," Baron said. "It's a tragic loss for jazz history and the city of New Orleans."

Originally, the building housed the Karnofsky Tailor Shop, where young Armstrong worked as a errand boy and shine boy in the early 1910s. It was during this time that the Karnofsky family, Jewish immigrants from Russia, significantly influenced Armstrong and even gave him his first instrument.

Morris Karnofsky, one of Armstrong's boyhood friends, later opened the city's first jazz record store on North Rampart Street, which Armstrong frequented.

According to Baron, "The Karnofskys saw potential in Armstrong and supported him in his early musical career. They even loaned him money to buy his first cornet, under the condition that he works for them for another year."

Armstrong went on to become a jazz and popular music icon, known for his trumpet playing and singing. His influence on jazz and American music is still felt today.

Despite the historical significance of the building, efforts to restore it as a city landmark have failed to materialize. A real estate firm, which had plans to restore the building as a homage to jazz history, now faces the challenge of rebuilding from the ground up.

"It's a reminder of the fragility of our history and the importance of preserving it," Baron said. "We can only hope that the memory of the Karnofsky Tailor Shop and its influence on Louis Armstrong's career will live on."

As the city of New Orleans begins the long process of rebuilding after Hurricane Ida, the loss of this historic building is a reminder of the importance of preserving the past and the role it plays in shaping the future.

The music of Louis Armstrong continues to inspire generations, a testament to the enduring power of jazz and the resilience of the city and its people.

"Louis Armstrong's music is a beacon of hope and joy, even in the darkest of times," Baron said. "It's a reminder that no matter what challenges we face, the power of music and the human spirit can help us overcome them."

The Karnofsky Tailor Shop may be gone, but the legacy of Louis Armstrong and the role the Karnofsky family played in his early career will live on in the hearts and minds of jazz fans around the world.

In the words of Louis Armstrong himself, "Music is a language that doesn't speak in particular words. It speaks in emotions, and if it's in the bones, it's in the bones."

Despite the loss of the Karnofsky Tailor Shop, the music of Louis Armstrong continues to speak to us in a language that transcends time and place.

As the city of New Orleans rebuilds, the memory of the Karnofsky Tailor Shop and its influence on jazz history will live on in the music of Louis Armstrong and the hearts and minds of jazz fans around the world.

Angela Onwuachi-Willig, dean of Boston University's law school, emphasized the importance of acknowledging the historical context of these cases. She stated, "Understanding the long history of white violence against Black people is essential to addressing the root causes of these incidents."

Ashley Howard, an assistant professor of African American history at the University of Iowa, drew parallels between the trials and historical racial violence. "The danger faced by Black Americans in predominantly white spaces has not diminished," Howard said. "These cases serve as a reminder that the struggle for racial justice is far from over."

White allies of Black liberation have also faced violence and vilification. In the 1960s, civil rights activists were met with violence from white mobs and law enforcement. Today, as the movement for racial equality gains momentum, there is a growing fear of diminishing white identity and power.

Carol Anderson warned, "White vigilantism is not just about individual acts of violence, but also about the societal norms and laws that enable and protect such actions." She continued, "Until we address the systemic issues at the root of these incidents, we will continue to see the tragic consequences of racial injustice."

Michael Waldman concluded, "The Rittenhouse and Arbery cases are not isolated incidents. They are part of a larger narrative of racial rifts and deep-seated inequalities. It is our responsibility to learn from history and work towards a more just and equitable society for all."

Amateur Sleuths on Social Media: How Two YouTubers and a TikTok User Helped Unravel the Gabby Petito Case

However, Twitter started flagging Trump's tweets for misinformation in 2020, regarding elections and COVID-19, leading up to the permanent suspension.
